Market share gains enjoyed by Cisco Systems (CSCO) rival Arista Networks' (ANET) in the data center switching market already are reflected in its stock price, says Morgan Stanley, which downgraded Arista on Monday.Analyst James Faucette downgraded Arista Networks stock to equal weight from outperform, with a price target of 94. Shares of the maker of network gear for cloud computing were down a fraction, to 92.75, at the close on the stock market today.Arista Networks stock is above its 50-day moving average but has retreated from an all-time high of 95.97 set on Nov. 28."We are downgrading to equal-weight as current share prices give sufficient credit to Arista's share gain opportunities in the data center and emerging switch-router opportunities," said Faucette in his research report.IBD'S TAKE: Arista Networks is ranked No. 14 in the IBD 50 list of high-performing growth stocks, which is topped by chipmaker Nvidia.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Arista Networks in October said it had received U.S. customs approval to begin importing goods related to litigation with Cisco. The International Trade Commission could have enforced an import ban on Arista gear that was manufactured in Asia amid a legal battle with Cisco.Arista Networks has denied infringing Cisco's patents but also says it has modified its network software to resolve issues.Analysts had expected Arista Networks' gross profit margins to be pressured as it ramps up its U.S. manufacturing."We estimate that the data center switching market is on track to roughly double in size from 2014 to 2020, and Arista has so far grown to a recently reported 15% share of ports," said Faucette. "While switch-router use cases are still in early days, management believes it could represent a $1 billion to $2 billion opportunity by 2020, replacing part of the edge router market."Assuming Arista gains market share in line with its share of data center switches, we estimate annual earnings contribution of 60 cents per share. But we do not expect to see meaningful contributions until 2018."RELATED:Will Broadcom Chip Boost Arista Networks Vs. Cisco Systems?Can Arista Networks Keep Beating Wall Street Views, Or Will Growth Slow?Juniper Will Do Better Vs. Cisco, Arista, Says Goldman SachsCisco Rival Arista Networks Beats On Earnings, Sales, GuidanceCould HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?

Graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), along with Walt Disney (DIS), Expedia (EXPE), Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Kohl's (KSS) all had their price target raised by analysts.Nvidia had its price target raised to 80 from 66, with a buy rating. Nvidia late Thursday smashed Wall Street's fiscal Q3 sales and earnings estimates and guided analysts higher for the current quarter. Nvidia stock jumped into record high territory on the news. Nvidia has been boosted lately by sales of chips for gaming PCs, data centers and auto infotainment systems.Nvidia stock soared 30% to a record 87.97 in the stock market today.RELATED:Nvidia Stock Soars On Q3 Beat And RaiseWalt Disney's price target was raised to 101 from 98 by RBC Capital Markets, which maintained a sector perform rating. Disney missed fiscal Q4 estimates after the close Thursday on more ESPN subscriber losses, but the media and entertainment giant sees earnings growth picking up in the coming years. RBC said expense guidance for 2017 is better than the market feared. "We think this will drive a short-term relief rally. However, more robust EPS growth is still a full year away so we  remain Sector Perform."Disney shares rose 2.9% to 97.68.RELATED:Disney Sees Earnings Growth Picking Up, ESPN Weakness EasingOnline travel firm Expedia was upgraded to a hold from sell by Stifel Nicholas, and its price target raised to  130 from 116. Expedia  posted weaker-than-expected earnings on Oct. 27. But a Cowen report said it now has "increased confidence in a meaningful acceleration in Q4" for Expedia.Expedia fell 2% to 121.20.Hewlett-Packard Enterprise had its price target raised to 27 from 23.55 by Jefferies Group. Hewlett-Packard Enterprise reports fiscal Q4 earnings on Nov. 22. The consensus is revenue of $12.8 billion, down 4.5% year over year and EPS of 61 cents, up 13%. "While there exist some macro uncertainties, we believe HPE have many levers to pull to deliver decent results," said a report from Credit Suisse.Hewlett-Packard Enterprise rose 1% to 23.31.Kohl's had its price target raised to 58 from 51 by Telsey Advisory Group, with an outperform rating. Kohl's rose sharply after it released better-than-expected Q3 earnings Thursday that beat expectations.Kohl's climbed 4.4% to close at 53.22, a high not seen since August 2015. Shares had soared 11.5% to 50.97 on Thursday.

Stocks continued to advance in record high territory as shoppers kicked off another shopping season even as Black Friday fades somewhat in importance. Oil futures rose on OPEC optimism on output cut talks ahead of a Nov. 30 deadline.The S&P 500 joined other major averages in record territory, as the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq all rose more than 1% for the week. Apple (AAPL) retook a buy point. FANG stocks gained ground, with laggard Facebook (FB) moving back above its 200-day moving average. Retail and restaurant earnings were generally positive, though Urban Outfitters (URBN) was a big exception. Bad clinical trial news hit some drug stocks.Shoppers once again rushed stores for doorbuster deals on the day after Thanksgiving, the unofficial kickoff to the holiday shopping season. But Black Friday's in-store importance has faded as more sales are made online and deals are spread out throughout November and December. Still, online Black Friday sales were expected to top $3 billion, Adobe predicted. Wal-Mart (WMT) kicked off its "Cyber Monday" sales on Friday. Amazon (AMZN) predicted a record Black Friday, though that's not a surprise. Target (TGT) hailed strong sales of discounted Apple (AAPL) products. Star Wars toys from Hasbro (HAS) and others, as well as smart speakers from Alphabet (GOOGL)-unit Google and Amazon (AMZN) will likely be popular gifts.The Black Friday Score So Far: Target, Wal-Mart, Macy's, Apple, MobileUrban Outfitters (URBN) missed on earnings and sales, sending shares tumbling Wednesday back below a buy point. Dollar Tree (DLTR) topped earnings forecasts and while revenue fell short, same-store sales narrowly topped forecasts. The specialty discounter sees solid holiday sales. Off-price retailer Burlington Stores more than doubled earnings, crushing Q3 views. Sales just edged views. Signet Jewelers (SIG), parent of Jared, Zales and Kay Jewelers, and luxury watchmaker Movado (MOV), reported lower earnings and sales that topped views. Shares of both companies rallied.RELATED:Burlington Stores Stock Nears Buy Zone As Q3 Earnings Crush ViewsDollar Tree Sees Strong Holiday-Quarter Sales After Mixed Q3Signet, Movado Shares Shine On Earnings Before The HolidaysEli Lilly (LLY) said Wednesday that its Alzheimer's treatment solanezumab failed to deliver "statistically significant slowing in cognitive decline in a stage 3 clinical trial." Lilly will not seek regulatory approval. Shares tumbled to a two-year low. Other drugmakers working on Alzheimer's treatments also were hurt, including Biogen (BIIB) and Merck (MRK). Meanwhile, Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) halted a trial after new patient deaths, the latest setback for immunotherapy treatments. Juno shares fell sharply. Immunotherapy peer Kite Pharma (KITE) initially tumbled but bounced back.RELATED:Eli Lilly Alzheimer's Drug Fails Key Trial; Lilly, Biogen DiveJuno Stock Plummets After 2 Patients DieU.S. crude prices initially rose as the oil cartel sounded optimistic that it could reach a deal on curbing production by the Nov. 30 deadline.  But oil prices tumbled Friday, erasing nearly all of the week's gains, after a planned Monday meeting with non-OPEC members about their participation was scrapped. Russia has said it's willing to freeze, not cut, output. As for OPEC itself, there's still no detailed agreement, and members tend to disregard their quotas. Libya and Nigeria reportedly will be exempt. Iraq says it will join in cuts, but has given mixed signals. Iran also is a question mark. Meanwhile, U.S. crude supplies fell modestly in the latest week, though domestic production rose.RELATED:Oil Extends Losses As Doubts Grow On OPEC's Output Cut DealJack in the Box (JACK) earnings shot up 66% to $1.03, while Cracker Barrel (CBRL) EPS rose 18% to $2.01, both easily topping views. But both restaurants reported sales growth that was slightly below views. Jack in the Box, which runs Jack in the Box burger locations and Qdoba Mexican Eats, also guided low. But Jack shares broke out of a base to a new high. Cracker Barrel continued its rapid postelection run, with an analyst arguing that consumer confidence may rally in areas where the countryside-themed chain operates.RELATED:Cracker Barrel Beats On Profit, Raises Guidance; Will It See Trump Effect?Three China internet leaders saw their U.S. stocks jump after they reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings. It showed that the trend of more Chinese consumers going online remained strong. Weibo (WB), called the Twitter (TWTR) of China, along with web portal company Sina (SINA) — which owns 50.2% of Weibo (WB) — beat on the top and bottom line. So did social networking firm YY (YY).Palo Alto Networks (PANW) stock tumbled after the cybersecurity firm reported fiscal Q1 revenue and billings that missed lowered expectations and forecast current quarter sales below views. Palo Alto Networks blamed its miss partly on large deals that did not close in the quarter. Palo Alto has forecast a pickup in security spending by the latter half of 2017. IBD's 25 company Computer Software-Security industry group took a hit, falling below its 50-day support line, as Proofpoint and other stocks fell.PC and printer firm HP Inc. (HPQ) earned 36 cents a share excluding items, up 20% year over year and matching views. Sales rose 2% to $12.51 billion, topping analyst estimates for $11.9 billion. But for the current Q1, HP sees adjusted EPS of 35-38 cents vs. views for 38 cents. HP shares tumbled. Enterprise information technology firm Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), the other half of the former Hewlett-Packard, earned 61 cents a share ex items, up 17%, on sales of $12.5 billion, down 7%. Analysts projected 60 cents and $12.8 billion. For the current quarter, HPE forecast a profit of 44 cents at the midpoint vs. consensus for 46 cents. HPE shares neared a buy point.RELATED:Cisco, HPE View: Overseas Cash Trumps Cautious OutlooksStrong Notebook PC Sales Give HP A Lift, But EPS Guide MissesDurable goods orders jumped 4.8% in October, their best gain in a year. Core capital goods orders, a business investment proxy, rose modestly. Meanwhile, October existing-home sales, which reflect actual closings, picked up to their fastest pace since February 2007. But new-home sales, which reflect more-recent contract signings, fell last month after a downwardly revised September. With mortgage rates rising in October and spiking after the election, borrowing costs could chill housing.Cloud-based life sciences software maker's Q3 EPS rose 83% as revenue climbed 34%, both beating views. Veeva Systems (VEEV) also gave bullish Q4 guidance. Veeva shares broke out to a new high, clearing a buy point. Meanwhile, Medtronic (MDT) fell to a nine-month low as sales and guidance lagged estimates. It's the latest medical device or products maker to give weak results or outlook in recent weeks.RELATED:Veeva Systems Hits Buy Point, Outlook Beats On Expanding PortfolioMedtronic Dives To Nine-Month Low On Sluggish Diabetes, Valve SalesThe farm-equipment giant reported declining Q4 earnings and sales, but both were better than expected. EPS slid 17% to 90 cents, but analysts had expected just 40 cents. Deere (DE) said equipment sales fell 5% in Q4, but it sees only a 4% drop in Q1 and 1% for fiscal 2017. Shares leapt to a record high.Packaged-food giant Hormel (HRL) was upbeat on full-year forecasts, while Campbell Soup (CPB) beat on the bottom line. But Tyson Foods (TSN), hurt in part by lower beef prices, investments in the business and a jump in some feed costs, delivered weak results. The companies have faced more competition from fresher fare, which has become more popular.RELATED:Hormel Upbeat On Fiscal 2017 Profit, Campbell Soup BeatsTyson's Weak Profit Outlook Sinks Shares, Other Meat Producers

The stock market is usually pretty quiet around Thanksgiving, but a shortened week of trading offered up plenty of big earnings movers. The coming week could be more of the same, with earnings due from recent IBD 50 name Thor Industries (THO), Tiffany (TIF), Semtech (SMTC) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA), among others. If you think prospects are good for a…

Arista Networks (ANET) late Thursday said third-quarter non-GAAP earnings rose 41% with revenue jumping 33%, blowing past consensus estimates.Arista posted Q3 earnings ex items of 83 cents and revenue of $290.3 million. Analysts had projected profit of 73 cents on revenue of $283.4 million.In the current quarter, Arista forecast revenue of $315 million at the midpoint of guidance vs. consensus estimates of $309.3 million.Arista Networks stock, fell 2.4% in after-hours trading Thursday, after falling 1% to 82.08 in the regular session in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Arista Network stock had slipped to touch its 50-day moving average, prior to reporting Q3 earnings. Arista Network is No. 4 in the IBD 50 ranking of top-growth stocks, behind Netease, Gigamon and Nvidia .Santa Clara, Calif.-based Arista Networks has been taking share from Cisco Systems (CSCO) in the data center switching market, analysts say. Arista Networks' customers – such as Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) – buy its speedy network switches and software for use in data centers that provide cloud computing services. Other Arista Network customers include financial services companies.Analysts expect Arista Networks' gross profit margins to be pressured as it ramps up its U.S. manufacturing.The International Trade Commission may enforce an import ban on Arista gear manufactured in Asia amid a legal battle with Cisco. Arista Networks has denied infringing Cisco's patents but also says it has modified its network software to resolve issues.An Oppenheimer analyst, in a research report this month, speculated that Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) might want to consider acquiring Arista Networks.RELATED:Could HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?Arista Provides A Good Lesson In Early Stage BasesArista Investors Work Around Cisco ITC Patent Win, Drive Stock Up

Stocks moved off their worst levels of the morning, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 0.1% in the stock market today to a fresh all-time high.The Nasdaq fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 declined 0.1%.Eli Lilly's (LLY) experimental late-stage drug failed to slow memory loss in patients with Alzheimer's disease. The company will no longer seek regulatory approval for the drug, solanezumab. Shares tanked 12%. Biogen (BIIB) and Merck (MRK) shares were also impacted by Lilly's trial results falling 4.4% and 0.8%, respectively.Deere (DE) gained 10% after indicating that better performance lies ahead. Although Q4 earnings and sales still declined vs. last year's Q4 figures, the company said revenue would continue to fall, but by less than Wall Street expected. Shares are trading at an all-time high.IBD 50 stock, Veeva Systems (VEEV) raced past earnings and sales estimates Tuesday after the bell. The life-sciences software company reported adjusted EPS of 22 cents vs. the forecasted 16 cents. Revenue increased to $142.8 million, topping the $135.8 million consensus. Additionally, Veeva's operating margin increased 33.3%, significantly above consensus 27.1%.Veeva's Vault platform has become the main driver of total bookings for the first time, and represented about 33% of subscription revenue. Vault is a cloud-based system that streamlines pharmaceutical regulatory compliance.The stock is up 7%, and is breaking out of a cup base with a 42.68 entry point. The relative strength line hit a new high today on the gap up, which is a particularly bullish indicator.Oil prices dropped 1% as the dollar index soared 0.6% to new 13-year highs on better-than-expected durable goods orders. October durable goods orders increased 4.8% beating the 1.5% estimate. September's figures were also revised upwards from -0.1% to 0.4%.Gold prices also fell in conjunction with the rising dollar and were down 1.7%.Weekly initial jobless claims came in at 251,000 vs. 250,000 expected.New-home sales fell 1.9% in October after a downwardly revised September.The September Housing Price Index rose 0.6% vs. +0.7%.Markit's preliminary November manufacturing purchasing managers' index was 53.9 vs. 53.4 expected.Still to come: the weekly oil inventories report from the EIA at 10:30 a.m. ET; and the minutes from the Federal Reserve's November meeting at 2 p.m. ET.Eli Lilly Alzheimer's Drug Fails Key Trial; Lilly, Biogen DiveVeeva Beats, Guides High; Urban Outfitters Misses; HPE, HP Inc. MixedDeere Stock Soars As Q4 Earnings Crush Estimates

HP Inc. (HPQ) increased its personal computer sales in a challenging market during its fiscal fourth quarter, which helped return the PC and printer company to revenue growth after at least three quarters of decline.HP late Tuesday reported in-line earnings per share on better-than-expected sales for its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company earned 36 cents a share excluding items, up 20% year over year, on sales of $12.51 billion, up 2%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected HP to generate sales of $11.9 billion, down 2%, in Q4.It was HP's first quarter of sales growth since it split from Hewlett-Packard a year ago. That transaction also spawned Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which edged expectations with its earnings report late Tuesday.But HP's current-quarter EPS guidance disappointed investors. It expects non-GAAP earnings per share of 35 to 38 cents in fiscal Q1. The midpoint of its guidance is below the 38 cents expected by Wall Street.HP stock tumbled 6.8% to 14.86 on the stock market today, falling below its 50-day line.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 49. But there are more attractive stocks out there for investors to consider. Read this week's installment of the IBD feature, Stocks Near A Buy Zone.Three analysts who are neutral on HP shares increased their price targets on the stock on Wednesday.BMO Capital Markets analyst Tim Long reiterated his market perform rating on HP, but upped his price target to 16 from 13.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um maintained his market perform rating on HP and set a valuation range of 15 to 16.50, up from 14 to 15.UBS analyst Steven Milunovich kept his neutral rating on HP, but raised his price target to 16 from 15.HP's PC sales rose 4% year over year to $8.02 billion in the October quarter. Sales in its printer and supplies unit fell 8% to $4.56 billion. Notebook PC sales rose 6% to $4.64 billion and accounted for 58% of revenue in the company's personal computer unit last quarter. Desktop and workstation PC sales also grew in Q4. Consumer PC revenue rose 7% for HP last quarter while commercial PC revenue increased 3%.HP management credited its strong PC performance to its focus on targeted segments of the market like premium consumer and gaming PCs.HP's sales of premium consumer PC likely benefited from Apple's (AAPL) delayed notebook refresh, Long said in a research note. And HP's gaming PCs got a boost from a recent graphics card refresh, he said."We are impressed with the performance, but remain concerned that the broader (PC) market continues to decline and share gains will become increasingly harder to attain," Long said.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani reiterated his sector perform rating on HP and price target of 16.Investor concerns with HP include its struggling printer supplies unit, the potential for PC component shortages and general macro uncertainty, Daryanani said.RELATED:HP Gains On Lenovo In PCs; Apple Mac Sales TumbleApple MacBook Pro Refresh Unlikely To Boost Top Line Much

Stocks opened lower Wednesday, despite a surprise jump in October durable goods orders.The Dow industrials were down a fraction, the S&P 500 was off 0.3% and the Nasdaq 0.6%.Deere (DE) reaped an 8% premarket gain on fiscal fourth-quarter earnings and revenue that fell much less than expected. Management said company performance had improved amid the global farm and construction market downturns, and projected annual savings from efficiency initiatives of $500 million by 2018. Deere shares topped the previous high of 98.23, set in June 2015.Eli Lilly (LLY) unraveled 13% after announcing that stage 3 trial results of its Alzheimer's treatment solanezumab failed to show meaningful results. Investors applied selling pressure to other drugmakers with closely watched trials, sending Biogen (BIIB) down 6% and Merck (MRK) off 2%.The Hewlett Packard companies, divided in two a year ago, slipped after reporting results late Tuesday. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is the cloud services and corporate networking business, and HP Inc. (HPQ) is focused on PC and printing products. HP dropped 3% at the open after reporting in-line fiscal Q4 earnings and better-than-forecast revenue, but guided Q1 earnings below estimates. Hewlett Packard Enterprise slipped less than 1%, after reporting mixed Q4 results and also offered weak guidance.Among IBD 50 stocks, Veeva Systems (VEEV) surged 8%. The provider of cloud-based sales and marketing software reported an 83% earnings jump for its fiscal fourth quarter, far above analyst targets and the company biggest jump since last year's June quarter. A 34% revenue jump also easily cleared estimates and management raised its fiscal first-quarter guidance to above the consensus view.Veeva ended Tuesday's session less than 3% below a 42.56 buy point in an 11-week cup base.The stock market today receives a heavy dose of data, opening with the Commerce Department reporting durable goods orders surged 4.8% in October.  That sharply reversed September's 0.1% decline and clobbered economist expectations for a 1.5% increase. Minus transportation, orders rose 1%, vs. the prior month's 0.2% increase and consensus views for another 0.2% gain.Initial jobless claims jumped nearly 8%, to 251,000, in the week ended Nov. 19, according to the Labor Department. That wasn't far from consensus estimates for an increase to 250,000. The four-week average eased to 251,000 in a second straight decline.The Federal Housing Finance Agency's Housing Price Index rose 0.6%, showing home price gains steady in September. The increase was just a shade below August's 0.7% rise, as well as consensus views for another 0.7% gain.Next up: London-based researcher Markit's preliminary November manufacturing purchasing manager's index arrives at 9:45 a.m. ET.October new home sales data from the Commerce Department are due out at 10 a.m. ET. A final estimate on November consumer sentiment from the University of Michigan is expected at 10 a.m. ET. And the weekly oil inventories report from the Energy Information Administration rolls out at 10:30 a.m.ET.Last, far from least, minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's Nov. 1-2 meeting are scheduled for release at 2 p.m. ET.Crude futures dipped, with West Texas Intermediate down 1% to $47.58 a barrel and trading about 5% higher for the week. Gold prices were off more than 1% to $1,193 an ounce, about even on the week. The dollar gained ground. Bonds dropped, lifting the 10-year yield 7 basis points to 2.38%.On the international front, China's markets posted very narrow losses. In Japan, the Tokyo Stock Exchange was closed for a one-day holiday. Trade in Europe remained turned lower in afternoon action, the FTSE 100 in London fell 0.3%, the DAX in Frankfurt was down 0.6% and the CAC 40 in Paris showed a 0.5% loss.Major global markets remain open through the week, aside from Tokyo's closure today. U.S. markets will be closed Thursday, and will re-open for a short session Friday with stock markets closing at 1 p.m. ET and bond markets shutting up shop at 2 p.m.RELATED:Eli Lilly Alzheimer's Drug Fails Key Trial

Like the ruthless character of Negan on "The Walking Dead," Apple has seized everything worthwhile from rivals in the smartphone industry.Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Walkley on Monday estimated that Apple took 106% of smartphone industry profits in the third quarter. Its share is more than 100% because other vendors lost money in the business, resulting in Apple having more smartphone profit than the industry netted overall.Apple's smartphone operating profit totaled $10.84 billion in Q3, vs. the industry total of $10.28 billion, Walkley said. Smartphone vendors that lost money in Q3 included Microsoft (MSFT), BlackBerry (BBRY), Lenovo, LG and HTC, he said. His report excludes a large portion of Chinese smartphone makers that do not provide profit information.Earlier this month, BMO Capital Markets estimated that Apple grabbed 104% of smartphone industry profits in Q3.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock on Monday retook a previous buy point of 110.33. For more information, read the article "Apple Is A Buy; Veeva, HPE, Urban Outfitters Near Breakouts With Earnings Due: Action Plan."Apple benefited from the launch of its iPhone 7 and missteps by chief rival Samsung, Walkley said. In Q2, Apple accounted for 75% of smartphone industry profit, he said.Samsung accounted for 1% of smartphone industry operating profit in Q3, or $87 million. The South Korean electronics firm was stung by a costly recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone. Samsung ceased production and sales of the device after scores of units overheated or caught fire because of defective batteries.Apple has had its own quality control issues lately. Apple on Monday announced that it will replace defective batteries in iPhone 6S handsets produced during two months last fall."Apple has determined that a very small number of iPhone 6S devices may unexpectedly shut down," the company said in a statement. "This is not a safety issue and only affects devices within a limited serial number range that were manufactured between September and October 2015."Apple stock rose 1.5% to 111.75 in the stock market today, retaking ta 110.33 buy point.RELATED:Apple iPhone 7 In Short Supply In U.S., China; Plus Models ScarceSmartphone Shake-Up: Samsung Slips, China Expands, iPhone 8 Pending

Cloud networking gear maker Arista Networks (ANET) will continue to gain market share, from Cisco Systems (CSCO) and others, and could be looking at multibillion-dollar annual revenue within three years, a Needham analyst said Monday.Needham's Alex Henderson raised his price target on Arista Networks stock to 110 from 105, ahead of the company's Q3 earnings report after the close Thursday.Arista Networks stock, however, fell a fraction in the stock market today to 84.75, just its second decline in the past 10 trading days."We think Arista is going to be a major technology company and achieve a multibillion revenue base over the next three to five years," Henderson wrote in his research note. Arista posted revenue of $838 million last year.IBD'S TAKE: A midmonth bounce off its 50-day moving average confirmed Arista Networks as a top stock, solidifying its standing in the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks, where it currently sits at No. 5. See what four stocks rank higher.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Q3 revenue to jump 30% from Q3 2015, to $283.4 million, with EPS ex items rising 24% to 73 cents. As the company grows, those growth rates are still high but declining.Henderson, though, says the company can sustain 30%-plus growth, in part thanks to "market-share gains at Cisco's expense."Arista makes routers, switches, storage-area-network appliances and other gear used in cloud computing, data centers and network environments.Strong Q3 growth at cloud services leaders Microsoft (MSFT) Azure and Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services should translate into strong demand for Arista. "(W)ith Azure up 112% and AWS up 55% despite steep continuing price declines, the scale-out market looks exceptionally robust," Henderson wrote.An Oppenheimer analyst, in a research report this month, speculated that Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) might want to consider acquiring Arista, but no further talk of that or any deal involving Arista has since surfaced.RELATED:Arista Provides A Good Lesson In Early Stage BasesArista, A 2014 IPO, In A Buy Zone

Cisco Systems (CSCO) rival Arista Networks (ANET) stock rose Monday after the maker of network gear for cloud computing announced that it has received U.S. customs approval to begin importing goods related to litigation with Cisco.Arista Networks stock rose 7.4%  in the stock market today to 94.48 and came within 8 cents of a all-time high of 94.84 that dates to September 2014. Cisco stock slipped a fraction to 30.05.Tim Long, a BMO Capital Markets analyst, bumped his price target on Arista stock to 110 from 93.The International Trade Commission could have enforced an import ban on Arista gear that was manufactured in Asia amid a legal battle with Cisco. Arista Networks has denied infringing Cisco's patents but also says it has modified its network software to resolve issues.Analysts had expected Arista Networks' gross profit margins to be pressured as it ramps up its U.S. manufacturing."The favorable ruling from U.S. Customs and Border Protection is a positive for Arista and partially removes an overhang on the stock," said Long in a research report. "Arista had been preparing for a potential import ban by building inventory and preparing investors for a negative impact on gross margins. We now expect gross margins to remain more in line with recent trends, though there are still some legal risks regarding this and another patent."IBD'S TAKE: Arista Networks is in the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks, but its earnings growth might slow in Q4, a negative in CAN SLIM investing.RBC Capital hiked its price target on Arista Networks to 95 from 85.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Arista Networks has been taking share from Cisco in the data center switching market, analysts say. Arista Networks' customers — such as Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) — buy its speedy network switches and software for use in data centers that provide cloud computing services."Despite this morning's ruling, we expect the company to continue ramping its domestic manufacturing, as a hedge against potential Cisco challenges and future ITC rulings," Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz said in a research report. "However, this ruling could add some flexibility for Arista's manufacturing ramp, limiting the downside risk to the 80-85% gross margin range. It is worth noting that other factors, including component shortages could continue to impact the company's margin."In an emailed statement, Cisco said it "filed an enforcement complaint with the ITC in August which notes our testing of allegedly redesigned products and why we believe, the claim of a workaround is a thin veil to cover Arista's ongoing infringement and convince its customers, many of whom have strongly supported protection of intellectual property rights, that they are buying a product that is non-infringing."Cisco said an initial ruling in the case is expected in June and that  the ITC is not bound by the customs decision."We are also awaiting the ITC action in the '945 Investigation' involving additional patents we believe Arista infringes, and which has been awaiting decision for approximately a year," Cisco said.RELATED:Will Broadcom Chip Boost Arista Networks Vs. Cisco Systems?Can Arista Networks Keep Beating Wall Street Views, Or Will Growth Slow?Juniper Will Do Better Vs. Cisco, Arista, Says Goldman SachsCisco Rival Arista Networks Beats On Earnings, Sales, GuidanceCould HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?

Citigroup started American Airlines (AAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL), and Southwest Airlines (LUV) with buy ratings; Salesforce.com's (CRM) higher-than-expected revenue guidance won the cloud software provider price target hikes; and Raymond James upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to outperform.Citigroup initiated American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines and Allegiant Travel at buy. Citigroup analyst set a price target of 55 on American, 61 on Delta, 57 on Southwest and 185 on Allegiant."Key fundamentals are mixed with expenses likely to be up sharply in 2017 as fuel prices drift higher and new labor deals pressure nonfuel unit costs," said Crissey in a report. "The stocks appear reasonably priced to cheap, both in a historical context and relative to the market."Citigroup also started JetBlue Airways (JBLU), Spirit (SAV), Alaska Air Group (ALK), Hawaiian  Holdings (HA), and United Continental (UAL) all at neutral.American stock edged up 0.9% to 46.26 on stock market today. Delta rose 0.8% to 48.90. American, Delta, United and Southwest had big weekly gains after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) disclosed stakes in the carriers.RELATED:Warren Buffett, Who Called Airline Stocks A 'Death Trap,' Invests In Big 4Delta October Unit Revenue In Line, Alaska Air Traffic Outpaces CapacitySouthwest Is Only Airline That Sees Worse Unit Revenue; Stock DivesJetBlue Warns On Q4, Spirit Sees Improving Unit RevenueWedbush hiked its price target on Salesforce.com to 98 from 96, Mizuho Securities to 95 from 85, and BMO Capital Markets to 90 from 86. Salesforce.com late Thursday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views and also forecast current-quarter and fiscal 2018 revenue above expectations. San Francisco-based Salesforce.com said in fiscal 2018 it expects revenue of about $10.1 billion-$10.15 billion, up 21% at the midpoint, vs. consensus estimates of $10.08 billion."Most importantly, reported billings grew 19% (year-over-year), and we calculate that organic (credit card) billings grew by about 21%," said Keith Bachman, a BMO Capital analyst in a report.Shares rose 3.4% to 77.77 Friday.RELATED:Salesforce.com Fiscal Q3 Beats, Sales Guidance Top Views, Shares UpSalesforce.com M&A Scorecard Raises Questions On Growth, TargetsSalesforce.com Officially Rules Out Twitter BidPacific Crest Securities upped its price target on Applied Materials, a maker of semiconductor manufacturing gear, to 37 from 35; Citigroup bumped up its price target to 38 from 37. Applied Materials late Thursday delivered mixed fiscal Q4 results but gave current-quarter guidance ahead of Wall Street's views. Applied materials stock has popped 64% in 2016. The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99.Applied Materials stock rose 1 cent to 30.74. Intraday, shares rose to 31.25, a 16-year high and briefly above a 31.17 buy point.RELATED:Applied Materials Earnings Soar, Guidance Strong, But Sales Just MissApplied Materials Makes 'Compelling Case' For Growth In Chip Gear SectorRaymond James upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which reports fiscal Q4 earnings on Nov. 22, to outperform. Analyst Simon Leopold set a price target of 29 on HPE stock. With HPE's planned spin off its enterprise services and software businesses, he expects improved free cash flow growth.Shares dipped 1.2% to 23.31. Shares rose to 23.85 intraday, briefly crossing 23.63 buy point.RELATED:Could HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?In other analyst moves, Macquarie Securities downgraded Citigroup (C) to neutral; Raymond James hiked its price target on Best Buy (BBY) to 53 from 45;  RBC Capital lowered its price target on Wal-Mart Stores (WMT)  to 42 from 47. Jefferies hiked its price target on chipmaker Marvell Technology (MRVL) to 18 from 16. BTIG Research upped its price target on Dish Network (DISH) to 90 from 85. Aegis Capital started Match Group (MTCH) with a buy rating and a price target of 20.

Having skin in the game matters. Especially with mutual fund managers. Funds with at least one manager who has a lot of their own money invested in the fund are more likely to outperform than funds whose managers have little or none of their cash on the line, according to a recent report by Russel Kinnel, director of fund research for Morningstar Inc.Among the 100 largest mutual funds tracked by the research firm, 56 have at least one manager who has more than $500,000 of his own money invested in the fund. Thirty-one of the 50 — or 62% — with the best average annual gains over the five years through Oct. 31 have at least one manager with more than $500,000 invested in the fund.Top performers with more than $500,000 of their own skin in the game include $43.6 billion Vanguard Health Care (VGHCX), $46 billion Vanguard Primecap (VPMCX), $32.6 billion T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth (TRBCX), $55.8 billion Dodge & Cox Stock Fund (DODGX) and $35.6 billion Fidelity Growth Company (FDGRX).Their average annual returns over the past five years range from Fidelity Growth Company's 14.30% to Vanguard Health Care's 16.82%.In the same period, the S&P 500's yearly pace was 13.57%.What stocks are driving these funds? Ironwood Pharmaceuticals (IRWD), held by Vanguard Health Care, is up 43% so far this year. The biomed-biotech drugmaker has an IBD Composite Rating of 83. It has benefited from the health care sector's Trump election bounce. Shares are 4% past their pivot, still within buy range.IBD'S TAKE: Learn how to find a stock's pivot, which is its optimal buy point.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is a top performer for Vanguard Primecap, up 53% this year. Earnings per share rallied 7% in the third quarter, rebounding from two straight quarters of declining EPS growth. The company reports fiscal Q4 earnings Nov. 22. The consensus of analysts is that EPS will rise 13%.Jeffries Group raised its price target to 27 this past week.FedEx (FDX) has been a strong performer for T. Rowe Blue Chip Growth. It is up 23% so far this year.The stock has a 95 Comp Rating. EPS grew 5%, 14%, 19%, 24%, 24% and 20% the past six quarters.The company is benefiting from the rise of shipping for e-commerce.Shares remain in a buy range after clearing a 177.46 buy point of a flat base.Jean Hynes, manager of the Vanguard health care sector fund, had at least $1,000,001 of personal money invested in the fund, according to Morningstar.The research firm notes that funds disclose manager investment-stake data in tiers that range from zero to more than $1 million. The tiers are zero, $1 to $10,000, $10,001 to $50,000, $50,001 to $100,000, $100,001 to $500,000, $500,001 to $1 million, and $1,000,001 and above.Three of Vanguard Primecap's managers had $1,000,001 or more invested in their fund: Theo Kolokotrones, Joel Fried and Alfred Mordecai. Managers Mohsin Ansari and James Marchetti had $100,001 to $500,000 of their own money at work alongside their shareholders'. The managers work for Pasadena, Calif.-based Primecap Management, which Vanguard has hired as subadvisor for the fund.T. Rowe Price Blue Chip's Larry Puglia had $1,000,001 or more of his own bucks battling side-by-side with his shareholders' money.The Dodge & Cox fund had six managers with $1,000,001 or more at risk: Wendell Birkhofer, Bryan Cameron, Charles Pohl, Diana Strandberg, David Hoeft and Steven Voorhis.In addition, managers Philippe Barret and Kathleen McCarthy had personally anted up $100,001 to $500,000.Fidelity Growth Company's Steven Wymer was also in the top tier, above $1 million.As of Aug. 31, 1,036 funds had at least one manager who had more than $1 million of his own money on the line in his fund.That's about 13% of the 8,025 funds tracked by Morningstar.The more of their own money that managers invest, the better their funds do. Forty-seven percent of funds — with a manager who had more than $1 million invested over the past five years — outperformed their respective benchmarks.That success rate falls to 43% for funds whose managers have $100,001 to $500,000 invested.And it falls further, to 35%, for funds whose managers have none of their own money invested in the portfolio.Among just stock funds, those whose managers' personal exposure was in the top tier had a 39% success rate. Just 29% of stock funds with no manager's skin in the game outperformed."It pays to invest with managers who invest in their funds," Morningstar's Kinnel said.RELATED:Introducing IBD's Best Mutual Funds 2016 Awards

Analysts expect Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to provide fiscal 2017 guidance at its investor day on Tuesday, with the strategic direction of its core business a key question following the planned spinoff of its services and software businesses.If Hewlett Packard Enterprise goes shopping, an Oppenheimer analyst speculates that Arista Networks (ANET), a maker of computer networking gear, would make a good acquisition.Arista Networks has been grabbing share in the data center market from HPE rival Cisco Systems (CSCO).IBD'S TAKE: HPE stock has dropped below its 50-day moving average, not a good sign. Its Composite Rating of 88 out of a possible 99 is respectable but the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks has higher-rated companies, with Arista Networks at No. 16."The companies (HPE and Arista) have already partnered and are very familiar with each other, making a combination easier," said Ittai Kidron, an Oppenheimer analyst, in a research report. "Arista's ongoing litigation with Cisco could complicate a potential acquisition near term, as could Arista's market cap."That said, by mid-2017, Arista could be in a position to have its (patent) workarounds certified by U.S. Customs, moderating the litigation risk."Hewlett Packard Enterprise in May said it would spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. Then in September, HPE said it would spin off its software business and merge it with U.K.-based Micro Focus International."HPE's balance sheet would boast a significant net cash balance of over $9 billion after the completion of the two spinoffs. An acquisition would likely come above HPE's stated 'sweet spot,' but Arista's value to HPE is undeniable," Kidron wrote.Some observer speculate HPE, with its remaining server, data storage, and wireless networking businesses, could be taken private.Jim Suva, an analyst at Citigroup, says the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be much more focused.At the analysts day, "we expect detailed strategic discussion with respect to the enterprise hardware group," said Suva in a research note. "While there are many moving parts to the business with divestitures, accelerated restructuring and separation payments, we believe investors are underappreciating the free cash flow generation."Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock was down more than 1.1% at the close on the stock market today, at 21.27, a one-month low. Arista stock was up a fraction, near 81, following four straight down days after touching a 14-month high of 87.62.RELATED:HPE To Spin Off Software Unit, Slims Down As Dell Bulks UpCisco Data Storage Acquisition Might Help Vs. HPE And EMC: BarclaysArista Investors Work Around Cisco ITC Patent Win, Drive Stock Up

Chipmaker Intel (INTC) got an assist from improved personal computer sales in the third quarter, but its high-margin data center chip business disappointed.Intel stock fell 5.9% to 35.51 on the stock market today, after the No. 1 chipmaker posted Q3 results late Tuesday.At least seven Wall Street analysts cut their price targets on Intel stock on the news.IBD'S TAKE: Intel stock cleared a buy point at 36.03 last month, but threatened to close below the pivot on Wednesday. Shares fell below their 50-day moving average line on Wednesday for the first time since late June. For more information on Intel stock, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Intel lowered its sales growth target for its data center chip unit to high single digits for the full year. That's down from projections for midteens growth at the start of the year.Intel's data center group accounts for about half the company's operating profit.For Q3, Intel reported $4.5 billion in data center chip business, missing Wall Street views for $4.6 billion. Sales in the unit were up 10% year over year.Intel's data center group remains the company's "crown jewel growth franchise, but near-term growth continues to disappoint," Canaccord Genuity analyst Matthew Ramsay said in a research report.Intel's largest unit, its client computing group, saw sales rise 5% year over year to $8.9 billion in Q3. Total sales rose 9% to $15.78 billion. Intel earned 80 cents a share excluding items in Q3, up 21% and topping Wall Street's target of 73 cents.But for Q4, Intel expects sales of $15.7 billion, vs. analyst expectations for $15.86 billion.Intel also forecast a decline in gross profit margin to 63% on a non-GAAP basis in Q4, from 64.8% in Q3. Its gross margin guidance implies non-GAAP earnings per share of 71 cents in Q4, vs. consensus views for 77 cents, UBS analyst Stephen Chin said in a report."The bulls will point to (data center group) reaccelerating and PCs stabilizing," RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a report Wednesday. "However, bears will likely point to further PC market declines, a deteriorating core enterprise business in (the data center group) and a slowing of cloud/networking-centric DCG spend."Intel's Q3 report is likely to weigh on companies with meaningful exposure to the enterprise and PC segments, including Cisco Systems (CSCO), Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE), Marvell Technology (MRVL), Micron Technology (MU), Super Micro Computer (SMCI), Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital (WDC), Pacific Crest Securities said Tuesday.All of the above stocks fell Wednesday except for HPE, which got positive reviews for its analyst day Tuesday, and Super Micro. Seagate, which reported earnings Wednesday, fell 2.9%.RELATED:Seagate Earnings Beat On Strong Cloud Storage Demand

Quick! Name a good Taiwanese stock.If Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) was the first to pop into your head, you're in sync with the iShares MSCI Taiwan ETF.That's not just because Taiwan Semiconductor is the best recognized Taiwanese company, but also because the stock is the largest portion of the exchange traded fund. Taiwan Semi accounts for a hefty 25% of the fund's portfolio, dwarfing most of the other 90-plus holdings.While that's a lot of eggs in the iShares Taiwan ETF basket, it's turned out to be a good bet. Shares of the chipmaker have been on a steady ascent this year, reaching record highs last month after surpassing the previous peak of January 2000.The ETF uses the company's Taipei-traded shares rather than the American depositary receipts, but both stocks mirror each other quite well. The U.S. and Taiwan shares are pulling back to the 50-day moving average for the third time since breaking out to new highs in June. Both charts bear a resemblance to iShares MSCI Taiwan ETF this year, which is up 20% in 2016.What about the other 75% of the fund?More than 8% is invested in Hon Hai Precision, a stock that surged as much as 31% from its May lows but has retreated back to a prior resistance level. The company is unfamiliar to most U.S. investors, but it is also known as Foxconn, one of the largest contract manufacturers of electronics in the world. Foxconn is one of the principal suppliers for Apple (AAPL) products; its other major customers include Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE), Sony (SNE) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).Largely due to Taiwan Semi's big weighting, 60% of the fund is in technology stocks. Some 16% is financials and materials make up less than 10%.The Taiwan Stock Exchange is up nearly 9% this year, putting it well ahead the Nikkei and the mainland Chinese indexes, which are down about 10%. Taiwan also is outperforming the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index."The primary drivers of this rally have been more macro-related than fundamentally driven, as earnings growth in Taiwan has increased in line with the broader emerging markets, but valuations in Taiwan have richened faster than the emerging market asset class as a whole," says Tushar Yadava, investment strategist at BlackRock's (BLK) iShares.On Nov. 30, the fund will start tracking the MSCI Taiwan 25/50 Index. It is quite similar to the current MSCI Taiwan Index, but the new one caps the largest holding, i.e., Taiwan Semi, at 25% of the portfolio. It also limits the sum of all companies with at least a 5% weighting in the index at no more 50%. The change is to better reflect rules on diversification, which the fund already has been following, iShares says. The caps are applied at quarterly rebalancings, so there may be some drift in between.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.RELATED:Chipmaker TSMC's Q4 Guidance Points To Strong Apple iPhone 7 SalesApple Contractor Testing Wireless Charging Module For iPhone 8

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) will spin off its software business and merge it with U.K.-based Micro Focus International, continuing a restructuring of one of Silicon Valley's venerable companies amid the rise of cloud computing.HPE said it will receive $2.5 billion in cash and its shareholders will own 50.1% of the new company.HPE late Wednesday also said fiscal Q3 non-GAAP earnings rose 9% in the three months ended July 31 to 49 cents per share, topping estimates. Revenue fell 6% to $12.2 billion, missing views. Analysts had projected 44 cents and $12.6 billion.HPE stock was down more than 1% in after-hours trading Wednesday, following its earnings and spinoff release. Shares rose 1.1% in the regular session in the stock market today, at 22.09.Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies last November. It formed Hewlett Packard Enterprise to focus on services and products for businesses and other enterprises, and printer/PC maker HP Inc. (HPQ). HPE in May announced plans to spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC)HPE had reportedly been in talks with private equity firms over the software business before Micro Focus surfaced as the buyer.HPW will still sell networking, data storage and servers to corporate customers. Analysts say CEO Meg Whitman aims to better position the company vs. Dell Technologies, following its just-completed acquisition of EMC, as large companies shift spending to cloud computing services. Companies are spending less on their own data centers, pressuring IT suppliers like HPE and IBM."We are taking another important step in achieving the vision of creating a faster-growing, higher-margin, stronger cash flow company well positioned for our customers and for the future," said CEO Meg Whitman, in a statement.IBD'S TAKE: HPE stock hit an all-time high last week amid speculation over a company breakup. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, HPE estimated non-GAAP EPS of 58 cents to 63 cents, in line with consensus estimates of 60 cents.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Price Target Hiked; Breakup Scenario?

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE)  is near an agreement to sell its software business to U.K.-based Micro Focus International PLC, according to people with knowledge of the matter.The terms being discussed value the assets at more than $8 billion, said the sources, who asked not to be identified because the information is private. A deal could be announced as soon as Wednesday afternoon, one person said.Micro Focus, based in Newbury, England, can use the assets to bolster its software products that help companies on a variety of fronts, including business applications, security and with data centers.HP Enterprise has been considering a sale of some of its software assets, people familiar with the matter said in July, in an effort to slim down its operations. The possible divestitures included a portfolio of acquisitions made over roughly the past decade, including Autonomy, Mercury Interactive and Vertica Systems.Kate Holderness, spokeswoman for HP Enterprise, declined to comment. Representatives of Micro Focus didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.Chief Executive Meg Whitman -- who split HP Enterprise from sister company HP Inc. in November -- is looking for more ways to pare down her company. Her aim is to make the enterprise unit nimbler to woo customers with more options from cloud providers such as Amazon.com (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT).Sky News previously reported that Micro Focus is planning to buy HPE's software business.

Sellers dictated the action Friday, but the selling wasn't intense after the European Central Bank, as expected, opted to leave interest rates unchanged. The U.S. dollar reversed higher after a soft start and the euro faded from its early gains after Mario Draghi acknowledged the ECB did not discuss an extension of the bank's current bond-buying program.Apple (AAPL) and Nike (NKE) lagged in the Dow, hurt by downgrades. Shares of Apple slumped nearly 3% after Wells Fargo downgraded shares to market perform. Nike also gave up close to 3% on a Piper Jaffray downgrade to neutral.The Nasdaq composite  fell 0.5%; the Dow and S&P 500 each eased 0.2%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE coming in higher than Wednesday's levels. Nasdaq volume was too close to call. Breadth wasn't too bad, with declining stocks having a slight edge over advancers.Retailers, miners, automakers and steel stocks lagged. Coal and oil/gas names outperformed.Oil prices soared after the Energy Information Administration reported that U.S. crude inventories fell by a huge 14.5 million barrels. October WTI crude oil futures jumped $2.12, or 4.7%, to $47.60 a barrel.In related news, after rising  nearly 7% Wednesday, oil and gas producer Apache (APA) tacked on another 7% after the company announced a significant discovery in a Texas shale formation that could hold up to three billion barrels of oil and 75 trillion cubic feet of natural gas. Houston-based Apache is trying to clear a consolidation that started in late May with a conventional entry at 59.69.In M&A news, Liberty Media (LMCA) added 1% after announcing a cash and stock deal to acquire Delta Topco, the parent company of London-based Formula One Group, for around $4.4 billion. Following the acquisition, Liberty Media will change its name to Formula One Group and trade under the ticker FWON.Elsewhere, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) gave up 3%, closing near its session low, as Wall Street mulled its latest earnings report. Adjusted earnings per share topped expectations, but sales fell 6% to just over $12.2 billion.  The company also announced plans to sell its software business to U.K.-based Micro Focus for $8.8 billion.IBD'S TAKE: HPE's tech service industry group is home to plenty of leading growth stocks. Read up on why it's important to focus on leaders, rather than laggards, at IBD University.Shutterstock (SSTK) gained 2% in the stock market today on news its photos will be available in Adobe's (ADBE) Photoshop software. Shutterstock is an IBD 50 name.Other outperformers in the IBD 50 included NetEase (NTES) and Leaderboard name Veeva Systems (VEEV).Top-rated new issues SiteOne Landscape (SITE), Twilio (TWLO), TPI Composites (TPIC) and Impinj (PI) also did well with gains ranging from 1% to 3%.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Keeps Slimming, But Where's The Beef?ECB's Draghi: No Bond Buying Extension, Expansion Talk; No Stock BuysOil Jumps On Second Largest U.S. Stockpile Draw; Brent Near $50

Apple (AAPL) was downgraded Thursday, a day after unveiling the underwhelming iPhone 7, and Nike (NKE) was downgraded as competition heats up in the athletic wear space, while Western Digital (WDC) got a price target hike.Apple was downgraded to market perform by Wells Fargo. The company released its iPhone 7 Wednesday, but the new phone is only seen as a minor upgrade to the current iPhone 6S. Most of the phone's new features, like the headphone jack removal and waterproofing, were leaked by the tech media in the weeks leading up to the phone's debut.Shares fell 2.6% to close at 105.51 on the stock market today.RELATED:What Investors Loved, Hated About Apple iPhone 7 EventApple Car Interest High In Car Owner SurveyIBD'S TAKE: Apple is ranked second in the telecom-consumer products group. But the stock has a below-average IBD Composite Rating of 36. For more data on Apple and to find higher ranked stocks in the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Nike was downgraded to neutral at Piper Jaffray, which cited competitive headwinds. Nike is teaming up with Apple on an Apple Watch Nike Plus special edition, which is optimized for running and fitness apps.Nike shares fell 2.7% to 56.17, dropping back below its 50-day average.RELATED: Adidas Isn't The Only Comeback Kid Nike Has To Worry AboutOlympic Winners And Losers: Nike, Under Armour, Ralph LaurenMizuho raised its price target on Western Digital to 60 from 54. The analysts have a buy rating on the stock.On Wednesday, the hard drive maker boosted its outlook, saying it now sees fiscal Q1 revenue of $4.45 billion-$4.55 billion, up from its earlier outlook of $4.4 billion-$4.5 billion. Adjusted EPS will be $1-$1.05 vs. its prior range of 85-90 cents and analyst estimates of 90 cents.Shares rose 0.3% to 53.47, consolidating in a first-stage cup base nearing its buy point of 54.66.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) was downgraded to hold at Jefferies. Last week, the yoga-wear maker and retailer reported weaker-than-expected quarterly sales and gave cautious guidance.Lulu shares ended the day down 3.2% to 66.08, hitting a 3-month low and nearing the 200-day line.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) was downgraded to market perform at Wells Fargo. The tech company said late Wednesday it will spin off its software business and merge it with Micro Focus International for $2.5 billion in cash.Hewlett Packard Enterprise also said fiscal Q3 non-GAAP earnings rose 9%, beating estimates, but revenue fell 6% to $12.2 billion, under views.Shares were down 3.2% to 21.38 at the close.RELATED: Hewlett Packard Enterprises Keeps Slimming, But Where's The Beef?

The second tech "unicorn" this year, following Twilio (TWLO), is galloping to the starting gate for its initial public offering.Nutanix looks to raise $196 million by offering 14 million shares at a price range of 13 to 15 each. That's up from its previous range of 11 to 13, suggesting strong interest from big investors.That translates to a market valuation of about $1.7 billion, which is below the $2 billion valuation placed on the company from a 2014 funding round that gave it unicorn status. Unicorn is a term used for privately held companies with a valuation of at least $1 billion.The biggest unicorns, such as Uber and Snapchat, get the most buzz, but Nutanix also has received a fair amount of attention. The company pioneered a field called hyperconvergence infrastructure, a market that research firm IDC estimates could reach $5 billion in 2019, up from $2 billion this year.Nutanix provides an enterprise cloud platform that converges traditional silos of servers, virtualization software and storage into one integrated solution. It's designed to reduce complexity and lower costs.Nutanix is slated to price late Thursday and begin trading on the Nasdaq Friday morning under the ticker NTNX.The IPO market, after a slow first half of the year, began to gain speed with the May 13 IPO of Acacia Communications (ACIA), which popped 35% on its first trading day. Acacia, a provider of high-speed fiber-optic communications gear, priced at 23.The stock closed down 0.5% at 102.98 on the stock market Thursday.Acacia was followed by cloud software provider Twilio on June 23, which jumped 92% on the first day of trading. It priced at 15 and finished 0.4% lower Thursday at 68.72.Japan-based messaging service Line (LN), up 50% from its IPO price of 32.75, has been another solid IPO. Line shares dipped 0.6% to 49.02.Other strong-performing IPOs include Impinj (PI), a provider of radio-frequency identification tags and reader chips, and Talend (TLND), a Big Data and cloud integration software maker. An investment bank recently initiated Talend coverage with a buy rating.IBD'S TAKE: IPOs are a wellspring of innovation and can be huge stock winners. But they can reverse quickly. Read this IPO Analysis: IPO leaders Can Fall Hardest In A Weak Market. It's important to focus on younger companies that are on the rise and doing new things, so IBD focuses on companies that went public within the past three years in the IPO Leaders column. IBD can also help you understand strong IPO bases.Nutanix said it has 3,768 customers as of July 31, up from 782 customers two years ago. Customers include Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Best Buy (BBY), Kellogg (K) and Nintendo (NTDOY), according to its IPO prospectus.San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix has been growing fast but also shows large losses as it invests big sums on sales and marketing and research and development.For the 12-month period ended July 31, Nutanix reported revenue of $445 million, up 84% from the year-earlier period, and a net loss of $168.5 million.For the quarter ended July 31, Nutanix reported revenue of $139.8 million, up 89%, and a net loss of $50 million.Competitors include Dell, which recently acquired data storage systems company EMC, in the process picking up EMC-majority-owned VMware (VMW), a leading provider of virtualization software. Competitors also include Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).RELATED: The 'Amazing' IPO Change That May Restart The Flow Of New StocksEverbridge Soars In Debut After Acacia, Twilio, Line IPOs BoomAcacia, Twilio, Line IPOs Prime Market For Post-Labor Day Pickup

Following the acquisition, Liberty Media will change its name to the Formula One Group and trade under the ticker FWON.Shares of Apple were down more than 2% after Wells Fargo downgraded shares to market perform.
