With its confirmation late Wednesday that it will spin off its software business, this following the pending sales of its services business to Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is ... what?The company that's left says it will be a more focused rival in today's enterprise "hybrid" cloud and on-premises computing world to Dell/EMC, IBM (IBM) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), but investors and analysts aren't quite sure what to make of things as they have quickly evolved."The stock has performed well on an aggressive share repurchase program and the projected incoming cash and stock from the two deals, but we do not see this as sustainable without consistent results for the remaining Enterprise Group business units," Alex Kurtz, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities, said in a research note late Wednesday. "Shares have outperformed on aggressive capital allocation plans, but there are no signs of demand stabilization."Pac Crest rates HPE stock sector weight, or neutral. Needham is maintaining its buy rating, but it's not particularly tied to actual business performance.IBD'S TAKE: Big companies can make big stock moves, while avoiding much of the volatility of smaller companies. Check out the IBD Big Cap 20 for the big companies that currently are performing the best."The company has become adept at pivoting, splitting and divesting as necessary to extract shareholder value out of a business that plus or minus a point is basically not growing," Needham analyst Richard Kugele wrote in a research report Thursday. "That said, we believe the value extracted from the spin-merger of the software business with Micro Focus adds at least $2 in value for shareholders to our previous $22 price target (now $24) and on that basis warrants a reiteration of our buy rating."UBS analyst Steven Milunovich also maintained a buy, but with a caveat. While he said in a research note that the recent deals benefit current shareholders, "the question when the dust settles is whether HPE will win as a more agile hybrid infrastructure vendor or have difficulty competing with larger Cisco and Dell with greater software and services assets."Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended Thursday trading down 3.2% to 21.38 on the stock market today. The stock hit a record high of 22.32 on Sept. 1.Late Wednesday, HPE confirmed earlier reports that it would spin off its software business and merge it with U.K.-based Micro Focus International, as one of Silicon Valley's true pioneering companies continues to restructure and focus on the rise of cloud computing.HPE will receive $2.5 billion in cash and Micro Focus stock valued at $6.3 billion at the time of the announcement. U.K.-based Micro Focus is traded on the London exchange. HPE shareholders will own 50.1% of the new company, which is expected to generate about $4.5 billion in annual revenue, more than $3 billion from the HPE side.In May, HPE announced the sale of its services business to Computer Sciences, with HPE shareholders owning about half of a company valued near $8 billion. This deal is expected to close in Q1 2017 and the Micro Focus deal in the second half of 2017.In announcing the Micro Focus deal, HPE said "the move enables a stand-alone HPE to realize its vision of being the industry's leading provider of hybrid IT, built on the secure, next-generation, software-defined infrastructure that will run customers' data centers today, bridge them to multicloud environments tomorrow, and enable the emerging intelligent edge that will power campus, branch and IoT applications for decades to come."It was only in November that venerable Silicon Valley stalwart Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies, Hewlett Packard Enterprise to focus on services and products for businesses and other enterprises, and HP Inc. (HPQ) to focus on PCs and printers.Also late Wednesday, HPE announced mixed results for its fiscal Q3 ended July 31. Earnings per share minus items of 49 cents topped Wall Street views for 44 cents, but revenue fell 6% year over year to $12.2 billion, where analysts had expected $12.6 billion. In constant currency, servers fell 2% and storage fell 5%, though the networking unit rose 10%.HPE CEO Meg Whitman is trying to create a company better able to compete with Dell Technologies, following its just-completed acquisition of EMC, as well Cisco and IBM, as large companies shift spending to cloud computing services.But Pac Crest's Kurtz said HPE still needs to show it can "buck industrywide secular headwinds facing on-premise hardware vendors and if HPE can establish share as a provider in new growth categories like hyper-converged appliances."RELATED:Cisco Systems Should Get Into The Chip BusinessHP Inc. Stock Rebounds From Weak Guidance

As rumors swirl that Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is planning to sell off its software unit, the company is preparing to announce its fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday.HPE closed Friday up a fraction, at 22.21, just below its all-time high of 22.32, reached on Thursday.IBD'S TAKE: HPE ranks No. 25 out of 46 stocks in IBD's Computer-Tech Services industry group. To see which companies lead the group, check out the IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the enterprise information technology provider earned 44 cents a share on sales of $12.64 billion in its fiscal Q3 ended July 31. It will be the company's third quarterly report since it split from the old Hewlett-Packard Co. The other company formed in the breakup was PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ).For the current quarter, Wall Street is modeling for HPE to earn 60 cents a share on sales of $13.1 billion.Late Thursday, Reuters reported that HPE is in talks with buyout firm Thoma Bravo to sell its software division for $8 billion to $10 billion. HPE CEO Meg Whitman wants to focus the Palo Alto, Calif.-based company on networking, storage, data centers and related technology services, Reuters said.On Aug. 11, HPE announced its intent to buy SGI (SGI) in a deal worth about $275 million. SGI makes high-performance computing systems for data analytics and data management.Wall Street analysts say investors are more interested in a breakup of HPE than the company's Q3 earnings report.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um, in a research note, said he expects an in-line quarter from HPE and that the software unit divestiture will be a "bigger focus."Um rates HPE stock as outperform, with a valuation range of 23 to 25.Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha said it's possible HPE could sell off other businesses and be entirely broken up within two years."We believe Meg Whitman is willing to usher in a major change to create value for stakeholders so that she may leave on a high note within 2 years of the HPE/HPI split," Garcha said in a research report Thursday.Garcha rates HPE stock outperform, with a price target of 25.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Price-Target Hiked; Breakup Scenario?

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan for Wednesday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day.Apple (AAPL) and Sony (SNE) are each hosting a major announcement event; Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Guidewire (GWRE) are slated to report quarterly earnings; and the Beige Book and Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) are due.The frenzy begins at 10 a.m. PT in San Francisco. People are awaiting the iPhone 7, of course, which is rumored to come with several revamped features: No traditional headphone jack, a new "Space Black" color and a waterproof design, among other things. The anticipated changes are said to be incremental, with many expecting a more impressive overhaul next year when the iPhone turns 10. Apple Watch and Mac announcements are also foreseen on Wednesday.The iPad and iPhone maker has been said to be losing smartphone profit share to Samsung, although the unfortunate timing of the Galaxy Note 7's battery issues -- i.e. they're reportedly bursting into flames -- is a "lucky break" for Apple.In stock news, Apple's 50-day line and 200-day line are converging -- a sign that short-term performance is improving. But shares have only risen a little over 2% this calendar year, underperforming the S&P 500's year-to-date gains of about 6%. Still, Apple has a buy point of 110.33.Apple dipped 5 cents to close at 107.68 on the stock market today.RELATED:Apple iPhone 7 Leaks Point To Waterproofing, New Colors, Better CamerasApple Finally Shapes A Buy Point; Watch Broadcom, Activision Apple's Smartphone Profit Share Slipping Vs. SamsungApple Schedules Sept. 7 Event For iPhone 7 RevealA little later on Wednesday at 3 p.m. ET on the other coast, Sony is expected to roll out the PlayStation "Neo," the latest edition of its gaming console. Expect both a standard and higher-end version of the new PlayStation 4, according to the Wall Street Journal.Rival console maker and Xbox parent Microsoft (MSFT) announced in June the holiday 2017 arrival of Project Scorpio, calling it "the most powerful console ever built."Shares of Sony have been trading steadily above their 50-day line. Sony shares rose 2.7% to close at 33.52 Tuesday, close to a 5-year high of 33.70 set on Aug. 26.RELATED:Why Microsoft's Project Scorpio Is A 'Game Changer'  Microsoft Confirms 'Project Scorpio' After LinkedIn BuyIBD'S TAKE: Can't figure out what to buy, and when? IBD University has plenty of investing tools, including How To Find And Evaluate Stocks.The tech company, which split off from its hardware counterpart late last year, reports after the close on Wednesday.Wall Street is projecting earnings of 44 cents on revenue of $12.64 billion.Hewlett Packard Enterprise is said to be selling off its software division, just a few months after it announced that it was spinning off and merging its Enterprise Services business with Computer Sciences (CSC).HPE shares fell 1.6% to close at 21.86 Tuesday. HP Inc. (HPQ) shares rose 1% to 14.63.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Q3 Earnings Overshadowed By Deal TalkGuidewire also reports after the close that day, with analysts forecasting per-share profit of 32 cents, a 9% year-over-year dip, on 8% revenue growth to $136.1 million.Shares rose 0.8% to 63.52 at the close. The stock has found support at the 50-day line and has a buy point of 64.10.Ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting later this month -- aka Will The Fed Hike Rates In September? Maybe! But Probably Not! -- look for the sixth Beige Book of the calendar year (there are eight such reports on an annual basis). The report contains anecdotal data on employment, consumer spending, manufacturing and other economic conditions, collected from the 12 Federal Reserve Districts.Also look for the monthly JOLTS survey, which highlights job openings and turnover for the month of July.

HP Inc. (HPQ) late Wednesday beat Wall Street's targets for fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings, but its stock dropped in after-hours trading on weak guidance.HP stock was down 4.5% after hours, following the earnings news release. During the regular session Wednesday, HP dipped 1.2% to 14.40.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based PC and printer maker earned 48 cents a share excluding items, up 37% year over year, on sales of $11.89 billion, down 4%, in the quarter ended July 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 44 cents EPS and $11.46 billion in sales.For the current quarter, HP's fiscal Q4, the company guided to non-GAAP earnings per share of 34 to 37 cents. It did not give a revenue outlook. Wall Street had been modeling HP to earn 41 cents a share ex items on sales of $11.8 billion."While the July-quarter print is good (upside to sales and EPS), the much softer October quarter is driving the stock lower," RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a research note. It is "unclear what's leading to the downtick in EPS for October quarter but the concern would be it's printing driven, given PC results were actually positive."Personal computers accounted for 63% of HP's revenue in Q3, with printing making up the remaining 37%.But HP's printing business brought in 73% of profits in Q3, compared with 27% for the PC business."Although the markets remain challenged, we have the innovation and executional rigor needed to continue to take profitable share and invest in the right opportunities to drive long-term success for the company," HP CEO Dion Weisler said in a statement.Excluding foreign-exchange impact, HP's revenue was down 1% in constant currency in fiscal Q3.IBD'S TAKE: Earnings time can be volatile for stocks. Investors looking to reduce risks at these times might want to consider investing in options, and can get help with options as part of IBD's weekly Earnings Preview feature.It was HP's third quarterly report since it split from Hewlett-Packard. The rest of the original company became Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).HP is the global market share leader in computer printers and is a close No. 2 behind Lenovo in personal computers. But printers and PCs are in secular decline as the rise of mobile devices has reduced the need for both categories.HP is broadening its reach into corporate copying-and-printing systems as well as 3D printers. In PCs, it is innovating with premium machines for gamers and power users, including the Omen gaming desktop and Spectre laptop.RELATED:HP Gains On Lenovo In PC Shipments; Apple Slips

With worldwide sales of personal computers and printers in decline, HP Inc. (HPQ) faces a tough road ahead.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company has seen sales fall on a year-over-year basis for seven straight quarters. Earnings growth has been hard to find as well.HP will get its next test on Wednesday, when it is scheduled to report fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close. It will be the company's third quarterly report since it split from Hewlett-Packard. The rest of the original company became Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).IBD'S TAKE: HP Inc. ranks No. 4 out of 15 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware and Peripherals group. But HP has a low IBD Composite Rating of 41. The top-ranked company in the group, Logitech International, has a Composite Rating of 91. For more details on Logitech, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to earn 44 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $11.44 billion, for the quarter ended July 31.For the current quarter, Wall Street is looking for HP to earn 41 cents a share excluding items on sales of $11.8 billion.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani on Monday reiterated his sector perform rating on HP, but raised his price target to 14 from 12. HP stock fell a fraction, to 14.37, on the stock market today."Heading into the July-quarter print, we think HPQ will report in-line to slightly positive results based on improved PC demand vs. the April quarter and a de-risked outlook for printing," Daryanani said.Market research firm IDC last month said HP's calendar second-quarter PC shipments rose 5.1% year over year, while the total market saw a 4.5% decline. HP is the world's No. 2 PC vendor in unit shipments behind Lenovo.Investor focus will be on HP's printer business, where the company gets about 80% of its profit, UBS analyst Steven Milunovich said in a research report last week.Rivals Xerox (XRX), Lexmark (LXK) and Canon (CAJ) have reported weak results but moderating rates of decline in hardware and supplies, he said.RELATED:HP Gains On Lenovo In PC Shipments; Apple SlipsApple Planning First Major MacBook Pro Upgrade In Over 4 Years

Stocks drifted lower amid rate hike concerns. Apple (AAPL) unveiled the new iPhone 7 and Apple Watch 2, but the modest upgrades failed to wow. Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and other grocery stores are reeling from lower food prices while airlines rallied on capacity plans from Delta Air Lines (DAL) and others. and fiber-optic results remained hot. A slew of M&A activity took place.Apple introduced its 10th-generation smartphone, the iPhone 7, and second-generation smartwatch, Apple Watch Series 2, at a media event on Wednesday. Both products are incremental upgrades to current-generation models. The iPhone 7 is waterproof to a degree, has advanced cameras and sports better battery life than the iPhone 6S series handsets. The Apple Watch 2 is "swim proof," has more health and fitness features, and includes built-in GPS and a brighter display. Apple also introduced a lineup of wireless earbuds and headphones. Nintendo (NTDOY) shares skyrocketed on news that it will bring games to the iPhone, iPad and Apple Watch.Apple shares fell 4.3% for the week as of Friday's close. The stock, which had been nearing a buy point, is testing its 50-day line again.RELATED:What Investors Loved, Hated About Apple iPhone 7 EventApple iPhone 7 Preorders Begin With Jet Black Model ShortagesApple Debuts Fitness-Centric Apple Watch Series 2 With 'Pokemon Go'The Nasdaq hit record highs early in the shortened week, but are down modestly for the week amid Fed rate hike concerns and after news of a North Korea nuclear test. The Dow and S&P 500 fell below their 50-day moving averages, but that's largely due to the support line catching up to the market's sideways action. Energy, fiber-optic, airline and biotech groups rallied, while grocery and retail groups struggled.Sprouts Farmers Market, SuperValu (SVU) and Kroger (KR) all cut full-year guidance as lower food prices slam grocery stores. Lower meat costs and broader price-trimming efforts by Wal-Mart are among the reasons for the food deflation. Food-stamp cuts also are hurting some grocers. Sprouts stock crashed 13,7% by week's end. SuperValu lost 17.3% and Kroger fell 3.1%. Retail groups sold off generally.RELATED:Fast Food Prices Have Never Risen So Fast Vs. Eating In CostsShares of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) got a bump this week after activist investor Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital disclosed a 9.9% stake in Chipotle. Pershing Square, in an SEC filing, said the Mexican-food fast-casual chain had a "strong brand" and "visionary leadership," and that its stock is "undervalued and is an attractive investment." The hedge fund also said it planned to "engage in discussions" with Chipotle over its business and direction. The disclosure comes as Chipotle tries to revive sales and customer loyalty after a foodborne-illness scare. Chipotle shares rose more than 4% for the week by Friday's close.IBD'S TAKE: The grocery price wars are adding to pressure on restaurants, which face soaring labor costs. But pizza stocks have been standouts. Papa's Johns is near a buy point as it expands to Mexico.Oil prices rallied as the Energy Information Administration said U.S. crude stockpiles fell by 14.5 million barrels, the largest weekly draw since 1999, but came as refineries on the Gulf were closed during Hurricane Hermine. Analysts expected a 200,000-barrel increase. The EIA is also using different methodology for calculating the data.EOG (EOG) announced Tuesday that it would purchase privately held Yates Petroleum for $2.5 billion to expand its presence in the Permian Basin in West Texas. Apache (APA) raised its 2016 capex budget by $200 million to $2 billion to explore its Alpine High discovery that's estimated to hold billions of barrels of oil.Enbridge (ENB) agreed to buy rival pipeline operator Spectra Energy (SE) for $28 billion in stock.Wells Fargo (WFC) agreed to pay $185 million in fines to regulators over claims bank employees had improperly created accounts in the names of customers in order to satisfy sales quotas and reap bonuses.Wells Fargo fired 5,300 employees after the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau alleged those workers opened more than 2 million accounts on behalf of existing customers without their knowledge. Prosecutors say those customers were charged fees for accounts they never ordered.Wells Fargo said it agreed to resolve the accusations without admitting or denying wrongdoing. It also set aside $5 million for customer remediation.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) confirmed that it would spin off its software business, merging it with London's Micro Focus. In May, HPE announced it would spin off its services unit to Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) Meanwhile, HPE also reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings, but revenue fell 6%, lagging views. HPE fell 4% for the week so far.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprises Keeps Slimming, But Where's The Beef?Finisar (FNSR) late Thursday posted fiscal Q1 earnings and gave Q2 guidance that handily beat Wall Street views. Meanwhile, smaller Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) hiked its Q3 outlook. Finisar stock leapt nearly 13% Friday and more than 17% for the week, hitting a 2-year high. Applied Opto, whose largest customer is Amazon (AMZN), climbed 16% so far this week, hitting a 10-month high. Telecom-Fiber Optics continues to rank as the No. 1 group. Analysts are using the term "supercycle" to refer to the big upgrade taking place to 100 gigabit-per-second, super-fast broadband networks, to accommodate video, the Internet of Things and more. Upgrading are telecom and cable broadband providers, but also the big cloud services and internet companies, as well as China. And this current cycle might last more than the usual two to three years, analysts say.RELATED:Finisar 'Stars Aligned' As Hot Fiber Optics Supercycle Keeps CyclingDelta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines (LUV) pared their flight-capacity growth forecasts, helping boost carrier stocks. Delta also said that it expects fuel costs to rise year-over-year in the fourth quarter, potentially boosting airfare and improving long-declining unit revenue as airlines pass those costs onto passengers. Cheap oil last year made it easy for airlines to expand and compete, helping drive down unit revenue in the process.Meanwhile, the breakout of Hawaiian Airlines parent Hawaiian Holdings (HA) was rerouted as shares fell nearly 4% on Friday, creating a 1% loss for the week. Skywest (SKYW) rose near the top of a consolidation for the week but was down Friday. Also, Panama's Copa Airlines (CPA) broke out, up nearly 8% for the week.RELATED:Delta, Southwest Capacity Plans Lift Airlines; Hawaiian Air Extends BreakoutGeneral Electric (GE) is buying Sweden's Arcam and Germany's SLM Solutions Group, suppliers of metal additive 3D manufacturing machines. But Pacific Crest says a GE or HP (HPQ) bid for 3D Systems (DDD) isn't likely. Volkswagen (VLKAY) is plunking down $256 million for a 16.6% stake in heavy-truck maker Navistar International (NAV). Diagnostics firm Cepheid (CPHD) is getting picked up by Danaher (DHR) in a $4 billion deal. Intel (INTC) is selling a 51% stake in security unit McAfee to TPG.RELATED:GE Buys European 3D Printing Firms, Lifting 3D Systems, StratasysVolkswagen To Buy Stake In Heavy-Truck Maker NavistarDanaher Buying Cepheid To Expand Diagnostics BusinessIntel To Sell 51% Of McAfee Security Unit To TPG

CyberArk Software (CYBR) stock toppled Wednesday after the company reported Q2 billings that missed expectations by $10 million.Analysts, though, downplayed billings as largely meaningless in CyberArk's perpetual license model and said better measures -- sales and earnings -- easily topped.Summit Redstone analyst Srini Nandury reiterated his buy rating on CyberArk stock and boosted his price target to 60 from 55. CyberArk "is profitable with plenty of headroom to grow driven by a shift in security spending from perimeter to protection of internal assets," he said in a research note.But by the closing bell on the stock market today, CyberArk stock lost 6.5% to 51.71. As of Tuesday's close, shares had risen 23% this year, while IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group had fallen 9%. On Friday, CyberArk stock touched a nearly one-year high of 57.57.IBD'S TAKE: CyberArk stock is ranked first in its industry group with a Composite Rating of 98, meaning it performs in the top 2% of all stocks. The group is ranked No. 43 out of 197 groups tracked, climbing from No. 186 over the past 13 weeks.For Q2, CyberArk reported $50.4 million in sales and 29 cents earnings per share ex items, up a respective 39% and 53% vs. the year-earlier quarter, and topping analysts' views for $48.3 million and 20 cents.License sales (comprising 59.5% of total revenue) rose 35% to $30 million. Maintenance and professional services added $20.4 million, up 45%. But $49.6 billion in billings lagged analysts' model for $60.1 million, though was up 3%, Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski said."While this marked the seventh consecutive quarter the company exceeded the high-end of guidance, the magnitude of the beat was the smallest it has ever been," Nowinski wrote in a research report. He maintained his overweight rating on CyberArk stock, but he boosted his price target to 60 from 55.Summit Redstone's Nandury said CyberArk is simply getting better at giving accurate outlooks. He and William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho wrote in separate reports that billings aren't a relevant measure of CyberArk's success considering its perpetual license business model.Ho kept his outperform rating on CyberArk stock.Nandury sees CyberArk as a strong acquisition target and, following a partnership with Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE) during the quarter, wouldn't be surprised at a near-term bid by the company. HPE will deploy CyberArk products in its managed service offering."It is entirely possible HPE may make a bid for CyberArk if the CyberArk's privileged account solutions find widespread adoption within HPE's customer base," he wrote.Current-quarter sales guidance for $51.5 million to $52.5 million met the consensus view for $52 million and would be up 30% vs. the year-earlier period. CyberArk's 21-23-cent EPS ex items view narrowly topped analysts' 21-cent view at the midpoint. But EPS would fall 15% year over year.

Shares of London-based Atlassian (TEAM) cooled off Tuesday, but the company got a rousing vote of approval from Summit Redstone Partners, which initiated coverage with a buy rating and said the 2015 IPO is taking enterprise software market share from such larger rivals as IBM (IBM), Microsoft (MSFT) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).Atlassian was founded in 2002 without a sales force, selling its software directly online, boosted by word-of-mouth. It makes collaborative software that businesses and other enterprises use to track issues, develop documents, provide customer and IT support, and more."TEAM is gaining share from larger peers like IBM, Microsoft and HP (that) are not as focused as TEAM on team collaboration solutions and communications," Summit analyst Jonathan Kees wrote in a research report Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: You want stocks in the top 30 (of 197) industry groups tracked by IBD, and the top 20 is better. Atlassian has helped boost its group, specialty enterprise software, into the top 20, as you can learn from IBD Industry Themes.He said the company was "unique from the start: from its differentiated, online sales model to its no-hassle, no discounting pricing to its high-growth, already profitable and generating cash business."Atlassian, which went public in December at 21, soared to a record high of 32.54 on Aug. 5, after posting June-quarter earnings and revenue that beat Wall Street expectations. Atlassian stock also broke out of a cup base at a 31.56 buy point on that date.Shares have since fallen, however, and fell 1.3%, to 29.95, in the stock market today.Kees started coverage with a 35 price target on Atlassian stock, saying "we believe TEAM's competitive advantages remain viable for the immediate future."Atlassian's customers include big names such as: BlackRock (BLK), Amgen (AMGN) and Sotheby's (BID).

Amid speculation that private equity firms are eyeing Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE), Credit Suisse raised its price target on the stock, on views that a company breakup is possible.Credit Suisse raised its price target to 25 from 21. HPE stock popped late Friday after online news site The Information reported that KKR, Apollo Global Management and Carlyle Group are eyeing the company. Reuters later reported that PE firms might be focused on HPE's software business, where revenue has been falling.After rising 3.5% on Friday, Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended trading Monday up 6 cents to 21.08 on the stock market today."We believe that the stock could be worth 31 per share in a breakup scenario," said Kulbinder Garcha, a Credit Suisse analyst, in a research report Monday.HPE has a market cap of $34 billion. But in May, HPE said it will spin off its enterprise services division and merge it with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) The spinoff is expected to be completed by March 2017.Private equity firms are likely focused on the remainder of the company. "The likelihood of a complete leveraged buyout is low given the relative size of such a deal," said Garcha, in the report.IBD'S TAKE: Privately-held Dell is expected to soon close its purchase of data storage firm EMC. The combined Dell-EMC will be the biggest shareholder in software provider VMware, whose stock has climbed 27% in 2016. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Garcha says while private equity firms could buy the software business, "servers may be of interest to Huawei, and storage to Lenovo." HPE would still have a networking gear business, which grew when it acquired Aruba Networks last year.At Needham & Co., analyst Richard Kugele said in a report: "While servers, storage, software and other business lines have their challenges, it would not be out of the realm of possibility in our view for the cash flow to entice private equity to take HPE off the market. Any acquisition would likely need to be at ($28 to $30 per share) to have a chance with investors."Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies last November, forming Hewlett Packard Enterprise, to focus on services and products for businesses and other enterprises, and HP Inc. (HPQ), which would focus on PCs and printers.

Workday (WDAY), HP Inc. (HPQ) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) gave weak guidance, while Heico (HEI) and PVH (PVH)  reported mixed quarterly results late Wednesday.Estimates: Q2 loss of 2 cents a share vs. 2 cent profit a year earlier. Revenue up 32% to $372.68 million.Results: Adjusted per-share loss of 4 cents on revenue of $377.3 million.Outlook: Q3 revenue of $398 million-$400 million vs. consensus for $401 million.Stock: Shares jumped 7% after hours on the stock market today. The shares are finding support at the 50-day moving average.Workday is a maker of cloud-based software for human relations, payroll and other business functions.RELATED:Workday Downgraded On Concerns Over Q2 Billings Ahead Of EarningsWorkday Push Into Financial Tools On Radar As Earnings On TapEstimates: Fiscal Q3 EPS of 48 cents on $11.46 billion revenue. No comps are available for HP Inc. due to its split with enterprise cloud-enabled services company Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) in November.Results: Adjusted EPS from continuing operations of 48 cents on revenue of $11.9 billion.Outlook: Q4 EPS from continuing operations of 34-37 cents vs. consensus for 41 cents.Stock: HP dropped 4.5% late.In addition to printers and PCs, HP sells scanners, servers and storage devices.IBD'S TAKE: Facebook and Google parent Alphabet are among 5 top techs that reported strong earnings.Estimates: Q2 EPS of 59 cents, up 16%. Revenue up 19% to $356.34 million. Results: EPS of 62 cents on sales of $356.1 million.Outlook: Full-year net income seen up 13%-15%, up from prior view of 12%-14%.Stock:  Heico shares closed up 1.2% at 74.24, below a record high of 74.66 set Tuesday, and rallied another 1.2% after hours.Heico is a maker of jet engine and aircraft parts and systems for the aerospace and defense markets.Estimates: Flat Q2 earnings at 58 cents a share. Sales up 3.5% to $1.167 billion.Results: EPS of 58 cents on revenue of $1.16 billion.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 75-80 cents on revenue of $1.235 billion-$1.285 billion. Analysts see EPS of 81 cents and revenue of $1.285 billion.Stock: Williams-Sonoma fell 0.3% late. The stock has been in a downtrend, unable to close above its 200-day moving average for the past year.Williams-Sonoma operates home furnishings stores under its namesake brand, as well as Pottery Barn and other labels.Estimates: Q2 EPS down 6% to $1.29, as revenue rises 3.8% to $1.94 billion.Results: EPS of $1.47 on revenue of $1.93 billion.Outlook: Q3 EPS of $2.35-$2.40 vs. consensus for $2.39. Full-year EPS seen at $6.55-$6.60, vs. consensus for $6.54, with revenue seen up 2%.Stock: PVH rose 1.1% late.PVH makes apparel, including Tommy Hilfiger, Calvin Klein and Heritage brands.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock jumped Friday on a report that private equity firms might target the company, which has a sizable market valuation.KKR, Apollo Global Management and Carlyle Group are mulling a buyout of the enterprise technology company, according to The Information news website.Hewlett Packard Enterprise has a market cap of $36 billion. Privately-held Dell last year agreed to buy data storage company EMC.HPE declined to comment. Shares of Hewlett Packard Enterprise jumped as much as 7.8% in the stock market today, before ending the day up 3.5% at 21.02.Hewlett Packard Enterprise in May announced plans to spin off its enterprise-services division and merge it with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC).Venerable Silicon Valley pioneer Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies last November, forming Hewlett Packard Enterprise, to focus on services and products for businesses and other enterprises, and HP Inc. (HPQ), which would focus on PCs and printers.Shares of Hewlett Packard Enterprise have jumped 50% since the restructuring, and the company has a market cap above $35 billion. Analysts have speculated that Hewlett Packard Enterprise is on the lookout for acquisitions, as it challenges Cisco Systems (CSCO), IBM (IBM) and others that provide a broad range of computing services to enterprises.

F5 Networks (FFIV) late Wednesday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that edged views, but growth from new products remains an issue, said Credit Suisse, which downgraded the stock to neutral despite takeover speculation.Seattle-based F5 Networks said revenue for the quarter ended June 30 rose 3% to $496.5 million, with profit up 8% to $1.81 per share minus items. Analysts had modeled EPS ex items of $1.79 and revenue of $495 million.F5 Networks stock rose as high as 124.76, just below a 125.01 buy point, but ended the day at 121.86, up just 0.3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Shares in the data center gear maker have shot up 24% in 2016 despite slowing growth, in part from speculation the company makes an attractive acquisition target.IBD'S TAKE: Gigamon is the top-rated stock in IBD's Internet Network-Solutions group, while F5 Networks is No. 4. Learn more about Gigamon at IBD Stock Checkup.Despite the Q3 beat, Credit Suisse analyst Sami Badri downgraded the stock to neutral. He also did this despite speculation F5 Networks could be acquired by a private equity firm or Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE)."The stock is now trading at our fair valuation of 125, including $1.1 billion of net cash," wrote Badri in a research report. "While we understand there is speculation for a takeout, investors should not rely on this to seek out upside in the stock and (we) point out that mature legacy IT companies are generally taken out between 3-4 times sales, which is where F5 is trading currently."F5 Networks is the leading maker of application delivery controllers -- electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks."Product revenue growth is now flat-to-down based on our estimates, driven by the transition from physical to virtual (software) ADCs as a percentage of revenue mix," added Badri.

Amazon.com's (AMZN) price target was hiked by Wedbush Securities ahead of Q2 earnings, Citigroup upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to buy, JPMorgan cut its price target on General Electric (GE), Credit Suisse initiated Allergan (AGN), and SunTrust Robinson Humphrey downgraded CubeSmart (CUBE) to neutral.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter raised his price target on Amazon to 835 from 775. Amazon reports Q2 earnings late Thursday. "After years of uneven profits, Amazon finally appears poised to deliver substantial earnings growth," wrote Pachter in a report. "We expect continued EPS growth from Amazon after its first outsized earnings beat in Q1. We expect Q2 revenue toward the high end of guidance."Amazon fell 0.7% to 739.61 in the stock market today.JPMorgan Chase cut its price target on General Electric 26 from 27. GE on Friday reported better-than-expected earnings, thanks to some notable items excluded from adjusted EPS. But its organic industrial revenue dipped, and industrial orders tumbled 16%. GE fell 1.6% to 32.06 on Friday, just below a 32.15 buy point.GE stock fell 1.3% to 31.64.Credit Suisse initiated coverage with Allergan with an outperform rating and a 327 target price. Allergan stock fell 0.45% to 247.85.Citi analyst Jim Suva upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise's stock to buy from neutral on "under-appreciated" free cash flow generation. He set a price target of 25. "While there are many moving parts to the business with divestitures, accelerated restructuring and separation payments, we believe investors are under appreciating the FCF (free cash flow) generation and net cash improvement," he said.Hewlett Packard Enterprise rose 0.8% to 20.21.Needham raised its price target on fiber optic parts makers Lumentum Holdings (LITE), Oclaro (OCLR) and NeoPhotonics (NPTN) to strong buy from buy. IBD's Telecom-Fiber Optics group is ranked No. 8 out of 197 industry groups. Needham hiked its price target on Lumentum to 40 from 35.Lumentum shot up 10.9% to 30.48, blasting through a 28.01 buy point.IBD'S TAKE: Lumentum is working on its second base since coming public in August 2015. It may hit a 28.01 buy point Monday. But it's just one of several strong tech IPOs from the past year. Check out five hot new technology issues in the latest Tech Leaders column.SunTrust Robinson Humphrey downgraded CubeSmart and Extra Space Storage (EXR) to neutral from buy. Real estate investment trust (REIT) stocks have run up in 2016 amid growing investor demand for dividend-paying stocks as global interest rates have fallen.CubeSmart fell 1.65% to 30.37.In other analyst moves, Pacific Crest Securities initiated coverage on Level 3 Communications (LVLT) and Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO), both with sector perform ratings; Deutsche Bank downgraded Tableau Software (DATA) to hold from buy; and Credit Suisse initiated coverage on Allergan (AGN) with outperform rating and a price target of 327.

F5 Networks (FFIV) stock rose Tuesday on speculation that private equity firm Thoma Bravo might buy the maker of data-center networking gear.Seattle-based F5 Networks reports earnings after the close Wednesday. Analysts estimate revenue will grow 2% to $495 million, with EPS rising 7% to $1.79.F5 Networks stock popped in early June on reports that it hired investment bank Goldman Sachs to explore strategic options. Shares rose 4.1% in the stock market today, closing at 120.60. The stock has shot up 24% in 2016 despite slowing revenue and profit growth, and it's near a 125.01 buy point out of a cup-with-handle base.F5 Networks is the leading maker of application delivery controllers -- electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.IBD'S TAKE: Gigamon is the top-rated stock in IBD's Internet Network-Solutions group, while F5 Networks is No. 4. Learn more about Gigamon at IBD Stock Checkup.Thoma Bravo, which acquired software provider Qlik Technologies this year, is interested in F5 Networks, the New York Post reported.Citigroup, in a June 7 research report, said: "We see potential (F5) buyers as Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), Dell, EMC (EMC), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and private equity."

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is likely to make more software- and security-related acquisitions, based on what the computer networking firm said at its Cisco Live customer conference July 10-14, according to a new research report from RBC Capital."While Cisco did not provide financial updates, comments and partnerships announced (at Cisco Live) suggest that the company is laser focused on expanding its recurring revenue streams and de-emphasizing legacy routing/switching in the future," RBC analyst Mitch Steves wrote."We think Cisco's strategy remains sound, and we believe future M&A and partnerships will continue to focus on software/security transactions," Steves said.IBD's TAKE: Cisco stock has traded between 24 and 31 for the past 18 months, but it's one of the most followed tech stocks and ranks third in the IBD Computer-Networking industry group -- facts you can learn at IBD Stock Checkup.Some analysts have speculated Cisco could buy a data storage company such as NetApp (NTAP) to better position itself vs. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).Cisco Systems stock is up 10% in 2016. Cisco stock ticked up 0.3% to 29.91 at the close on the stock market today. The company is scheduled to report its July-quarter earnings on Aug. 17. Chuck Robbins took over as Cisco's chief executive last July, replacing longtime CEO John Chambers.At the customer conference, Cisco showcased a partnership with startup SwiftStack, the RBC analyst said."On the storage side, Cisco is partnering with SwiftStack to create a model similar to Amazon Web Services (part of Amazon.com (AMZN)) on the storage space," said Steves.

New sharks -- private equity firms -- and wary old sharks like Oracle (ORCL) are snapping up computer software companies. Both are prowling the waters for one-time highfliers made more appetizing by weakened valuations. There's been a wave of software M&A in the first seven months of 2016. The stocks of many software developers have pulled back from highs struck…

General Electric (GE) is expanding its industrial internet presence in Europe, opening a digital foundry in Paris as it strives to bring its manufacturing processes into the 21st Century.Meanwhile, General Electric was the top performer on the Dow Jones industrial average Tuesday, rising 2% to 30.44 in the stock market today. GE closed above its 50-day moving average for the first time since May 2. Its stock has been forming a first stage base for nearly two months with a 32.15 buy point.GE Chairman and Chief Executive Jeff Immelt said the move is designed to update industry in Europe."Europe has the talent and infrastructure to lead a productivity revolution and the digitization of industry must be at the core of this mission," Immelt said in a written statement Tuesday.The Paris foundry is the first in a series of new GE Digital centers designed to incubate startups, improve collaboration and drive digital ecosystem growth, the company said. The Paris facility will serve as the hub of a network in Europe and GE plans to build four more such foundries this year.No financial terms were given but the company cited studies saying digitization will add more than 110 billion euros ($123 billion) in annual revenue for industry in Europe over the next five years.In addition to the digital foundry, the company launched two new software products based on its Predix operating system for industrial products.General Electric's Predix OS provides a digital platform for industrial devices such as locomotives, jetliners, power plant equipment and the like. GE Digital Chief Executive Bill Ruh told Investor's Business Daily in a recent interview that the goal is for every large industrial company to adopt the Predix platform."We’re seeing a trend where machines are getting smarter," and Predix is the platform that will enable those smart devices to connect in the Industrial Internet of Things, Ruh said.Earlier this month GE and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) announced that they would share products to develop the Industrial Internet of Things. HP Enterprise joined AT&T (T), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Verizon Communications (VZ) and others that have partnered with GE on its Predix platform.

Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google could step up the pace of acquisitions now that valuations are falling in Silicon Valley for hot, pre-IPO startups, says a Bloomberg report.Google, Facebook and Amazon.com (AMZN) have been called digital conglomerates, as they gobble up startups in artificial intelligence, virtual reality and other tech areas. Apple has been more reserved, although it's slowing growth may spur more acquisitions.The cash-rich internet giants are not the only ones that may go shopping. Analysts also expect Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE), Alibaba (BABA), Salesforce.com (CRM), Adobe Systems (ADBE) and IBM (IBM) to be among the buyers. Meanwhile, Microsoft (MSFT) last week acquired LinkedIn (LNKD) for a hefty $26.2 billion.It's an era of "unicorns" -- startups valued at $1 billion or more, based on venture capital and private investments. The biggest names among unicorns include resource-sharing businesses such as Uber, Airbnb and Lyft, as well as social online companies Snapchat, Spotify and Pinterest.While unicorn valuations have been tempered recently, that's also a trend among smaller startups, says the Bloomberg report.Mutual funds including Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price (TROW) recently have marked down the value of their holdings in startups such as Hootsuite Media, Dropbox, CloudFlare, Cloudera, DocuSign and Zenefits.Annual U.S. VC funding more than doubled to $63 billion from 2013 through 2015, but now capital has begun to flow more slowly to startups, and valuations are falling, says the report.Facebook and Amazon remain IBD Leaderboard stocks. Facebook stock ended trading up 0.9% to 114.38 on the stock market today. Amazon stock was up 0.3% to 715.82. Facebook could be forming a flat base, with a 121.18 buy point. Amazon is nearly 20% above a 603.34 buy point, a point where profits can be taken.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) earnings growth might slow amid mounting competitive pressure from Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and a “refocused” Juniper Networks (JNPR), says Goldman Sachs, which on Wednesday downgraded Cisco to neutral from buy.Cisco stock closed down 1.1% at 28.65 in the stock market today.While Cisco already faces “significant pressure” from Nokia (which this year completed its $17 billion acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent), Arista Networks (ANET), and China-based Huawei, new threats are emerging, says a Goldman Sachs research report. “We see heightened competitive pressure from a more focused HPE following its acquisition of Aruba last year and split from HPQ,” Goldman analyst Simona Jankowski wrote in the report. “In the data center segment, we see Juniper as a more meaningful competitor.”Hewlett-Packard split into two publicly traded companies last November, Hewlett Packard Enterprises and HP Inc., which focuses on PCs and printers. HPE last month said it would spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC).HPE now could be on the prowl for acquisitions, analysts say.“Cisco has been able to offset share losses in networking with share gains in servers, but we see those as largely exhausted now,” Jankowski said. “In addition, the significant increase in management turnover over the last few months raises execution risks over the medium term.”Some analysts have speculated that Cisco could buy a data storage company with software expertise in converged infrastructure.“We believe HPE now has a much more rounded networking portfolio with the Aruba asset, as well as a much stronger focus on enterprise IT infrastructure,” added Jankowski. “In addition, its leadership in servers and significant presence in storage (where Cisco only participates through partnerships rather than directly) can give it a competitive advantage in situations where the customer is looking for bundled solutions."HPE’s significantly lower margin structure allows it to undercut Cisco on price.”

Stocks were slightly higher in slow trading Wednesday ahead of a Federal Reserve decision on interest rates. Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Lowe's (LOW) rose, but Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Whole Foods Market (WFM) sank.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 rose 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was running below Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.Stocks got a lift early in the session from a report showing that New York-area manufacturing unexpectedly turned positive in June, helping to offset a bigger-than-expected decline in May U.S. industrial output.The Federal Reserve is due to release its policy statement at 2 p.m. ET. Economists expect the central bank to hold interest rates steady in a range of 0.25%-0.50%.Retail stocks were among the best performers, while utilities, medical and computer stocks were among the weakest.Home furnishings and repair retailer Lowe's rose 2% and reclaimed its 50-day moving average in heavy volume. However, the stock remains just below a 77.73 buy point following five straight declines.Lululemon, a yoga apparel retailer, rose more than 1% and is still in buy range above a 69.83 buy point. The stock is near a 52-week high as it rebounds from manufacturing problems several years ago that damaged the company's reputation.Cisco was down 1% after Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock to neutral from buy on concern that earnings growth could slow amid increasing competition from Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).Meanwhile, Whole Foods dropped 4.5%, slicing through its 200-day and 50-day support lines after the FDA sent a letter to the upscale grocery chain warning of "serious" food safety violations at one of its food preparation facilities.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) could go shopping for a data storage company with software expertise, as enterprise customers shift toward “converged infrastructure,” says Barclays.While Cisco has a joint venture with EMC (EMC) and alliances with NetApp (NTAP) and startup SimpliVity, the computer networking giant needs to own data storage assets as customers shift to converged data center infrastructure -- including servers -- that run on network management software, the investment bank said.“We believe converged infrastructure could be an area of interest for Cisco to tactically acquire software-defined storage assets,” Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz said in a research report.  “While storage is the glaring hole in Cisco’s portfolio, we think the company will move away from hardware-based assets as it attempts to shift to more software mix and value-added services.”Aside from Cisco, Moskowitz says Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), EMC, VMware (VMW) and Oracle (ORCL) aim to be players in the converged infrastructure market. EMC is in the final stages of  being acquired by privately held Dell.“Hyper-converged infrastructure relies more on software and seems to be ushering in the software defined data center. As such, consolidation may be critical for some of the systems-centric vendors to keep pace with innovation within the software realm,” he wrote.San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix has been gaining share in converged infrastructure, says the Barclays report. Nutanix might well rekindle plans for an initial public offering, analysts say.Hewlett Packard Enterprise, meanwhile, also is on the prowl for acquisitions, according to analysts.“Converged infrastructure is just a way of packaging IT components to drive efficiencies rather than a radically different concept that unlocks incremental revenue,” said Moskowitz. “We think storage vendors get hurt the most, implying only upstarts or companies not possessing legacy storage like Cisco are best positioned to benefit from this trend.”Cisco stock fell 0.65% to 28.84 in the stock market today. HPE lost 2.7% and EMC dipped 0.1%.

General Electric (GE) and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE) on Wednesday announced that they will share technology to develop products for the Industrial Internet of Things.Hewlett Packard Enterprise is the information technology and service company formed when Hewlett-Packard late last year split into two companies, HP Inc. (HPQ) and HPE. At the HPE Discover conference in Las Vegas on Wednesday, Hewlett Packard Enterprise said that it's now a preferred storage and server infrastructure provider for GE's Predix cloud technologies.Hewlett Packard Enterprise Chief Technology Officer Mark Potter said in a written statement that, "In order to fully take advantage of the Industrial IoT, customers need data-center-grade computing power, both at the edge -- where the action is -- and in the cloud."No financial terms were given for the agreement, but Hewlett Packard Enterprise joins AT&T (T), Intel (INTC), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Verizon Communications (VZ) and others that have partnered with GE on its Predix platform. IC Insights forecasts that Industrial IoT revenues will reach $12.4 billion in 2015, nearly doubling the $6.4 billion in 2012.General Electric shares rose 0.6% to 30.31 on the stock market today. GE stock is in a two-month consolidation with a 32.15 buy point but found resistance at the 50-day line Wednesday. HPE rose 1% to 19.35, hitting a record high for a third straight session.The accord is part of GE's transformation into what it calls a digital industrial company. GE has traditionally made big iron equipment like railroad locomotives, jet engines and wind turbines. It's undergoing a major transformation as it connects those devices with its cloud-based Predix operating software platform.Bill Ruh, GE's chief digital officer and CEO of the company's GE Digital business, said in a recent IBD interview that the company aims to have its Predix OS used by every large industrial company in the world.Predictive intelligence comes into play in Predix. Asked if that was the origin of the made-up word "Predix," Ruh said, "Absolutely. Deep machine learning is part of this. We couple it with physical machine models. Those are our secret sauce that differentiates us," from others creating software for the Industrial Internet of Things.

Is Meg Whitman, chief executive of Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), planning an exit strategy by year end?That's quite possible, says a Citigroup report, in light of HPE promoting company veteran Antonio Neri to the president's title last week."We do expect Neri could eventually lead HPE (perhaps a few quarters away) and we note he has 20-plus years within Enterprise Group," Citigroup analyst Jim Suva wrote in the note to clients. "That said, we do not expect Meg to exit HPE before the software spinoff is completed (scheduled for Sept 1)."HPE is selling off its software business to U.K.-based Micro Focus. HPE has already spun off its enterprise services business, which merged with Computer Sciences to create DXC Technology (DXC). Whitman's plans could be clarified at an analysts meeting expected in the fall. She oversaw the split of Silicon Valley pioneer Hewlett-Packard into two publicly traded companies in November 2015, with its printer and PC business becoming HP Inc. (HPQ). Whitman assumed control of HPE after the split.Before that, Whitman made an unsuccessful bid for governor of California as a Republican in 2010, though in 2016 she supported Democrat Hillary Clinton over eventual winner Republican Donald Trump in the presidential race. Still, she's been a big Republican fundraiser.Neri has been executive VP and general manager of HPE's Enterprise Group, which includes servers, storage, networking, and cloud solutions. HPE is competing with two other IT industry giants, Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Dell Technologies (DVMT), in providing next-generation data center technology. Cisco hosts a company tech conference this week.IBD'S TAKE: HPE's stock is down 4% in 2017 as the company restructures and is trading at a nine-month low. HP Inc. has gained 20% but the stock has weakened and is trading below its 50-day moving average. Learn more about their chart patterns and group peers at IBD Stock Checkup.HPE's server revenue has been flat and storage sales down. Shares of the company ticked down 5 cents to 16.80 on the stock market today.Neri will be in charge of "HPE Next," a new initiative focusing on growth areas but that is also expected to include more cost-cutting, says a UBS report. HPE is also expected to continue making acquisitions as growth slows.RELATED:HP's Rapid Growth In 3D Printers Threatens Stratasys, 3D SystemsHPE Snaps Up Nimble, Lifting Shares In Sector; Cisco Lurking?

Barclays hiked Arista Networks' (ANET) price target Thursday on views that risks of litigation with arch-rival Cisco Systems (CSCO) have faded and that Arista's marketing alliance with Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) will jell.Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz raised his price target on Arista to 185 from 161. Arista stock rebounded from intraday lows to close up 0.1% at 151.23 Thursday. On Friday, the stock was little changed. Shares have shot up some 55% in 2017."A crescendo of fading litigation risk, improving gross margin, and revenue upside potential related to the HPE partnership stands to bolster the model," said Moskowitz in a report.Arista sells network switches that speed up communications among racks of computer servers packed into the data centers. Santa Clara, Calif.-based Arista has been taking share from Cisco, thanks to customers such as Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Facebook (FB)."While Cisco and its litigation machine is not likely to go away quietly, we think the precedent set with the recent Patent and Trial Board ruling also sets the stage for litigation-averse, long-term investors to start taking a fresh look at the stock," added Moskowitz in the report. "It is good timing as we expect both margin and valuation multiples to exhibit increasing upward mobility."IBD'S TAKE: Arista Networks ranks No. 8 in the IBD 50 roster of high-growth stocks. Lumentum Holdings, Lam Research and Nvidia are the top tech stocks in the IBD 50. Amid a legal battle with rival Cisco, Arista has rushed to ramp up U.S. manufacturing in case its imports are blocked.Arista has denied infringing Cisco's patents, and it also says it has modified its network software to resolve issues.RELATED:As Networks Speed Up, Arista Gains Ground On Giant Cisco

Juniper Networks (JNPR) has diversified its revenue base thanks to its marketing focus on cloud-computing customers, says BMO Capital Markets, which upgraded the maker of computer networking gear to outperform.BMO analyst Tim Long raised his price target on the rival of Cisco Systems (CSCO) to 34 from 31. Juniper Networks stock rose 2.6% to 29.20 on the stock market today. With Monday's gain, Juniper Networks stock neared its 50-day moving average."The cloud vertical is now 27% of revenues, highlighting Juniper's increased diversification and lesser reliance on the traditional telco vertical," Long said in a report. "The cloud vertical has driven much of Juniper's recent growth and remains a significant growth opportunity as it architects its portfolio to meet cloud customer requirements."Juniper's cloud-computing growth is coming from customers such as Microsoft (MSFT), IBM (IBM), Facebook (FB) and Oracle (ORCL).Long, though, says other parts of Juniper's business are struggling."We hold no illusions about routing and security, and expectations remain low," he said in a report. "Routing remains challenged by soft telco spending and instances of switching displacing routers based on improving merchant silicon capabilities. Security has been a long-term headwind for Juniper, and the updated product portfolio may be too little too late. That said, given low expectations, any upside represents a call option on the shares."Juniper reports fiscal Q2 earnings on July 25. Juniper reported March-quarter earnings slightly above expectations.IBD'S TAKE:  While Juniper aims for a rebound, Arista Networks has been taking share from Cisco. Arista Networks is ranked No. 6 on the IBD 50, a roster of fast-growing companies. Look for more top-performing companies at the IBD 50, which also includes Lumentum Holdings and Lam Research.The company has been seeking a turnaround under its new chief executive, Rami Rahim."Juniper has underperformed year to date, and we believe the shares are ripe for a turnaround as more credit is given to the switching business, customer diversification strategy, strong operating expense management, and balance-sheet flexibility," Long said.RELATED:Cisco Lowers Sales, Earnings Forecast But Not As Much As FearedArista Price Target Hiked: Less Cisco Risk, More HPE UpsideIs This Tech Celebrity And Political Honcho Planning An Exit?

Gigamon (GIMO) stock popped Monday after Reuters reported the company has hired Goldman Sachs to explore strategic options a few weeks after activist investor Elliott Management took a large stake in the maker of communications-network appliances and security gear.Gigamon stock rose 8.9% to 42.80 in the stock market today, closing just below its 200-day moving average after hitting 44.55 intraday.Elliott Management in May disclosed that it had built a 15.3% stake in the Santa Clara, Calif.-based company.Gigamon could draw interest from Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), F5 Networks (FFIV) as well as private equity firms such as Thoma Bravo, according to Reuters. Gigamon's communications-network appliances analyze data traffic.The developments prompted Needham & Co. to hike its price target to 50 from 34.IBD'S TAKE: Gigamon was a member of the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks in mid-2016. Gigamon stock plunged in late November on disappointing earnings and outlook. The IBD 50 now includes tech stocks such as Lumentum Holdings, Veeva Systems, and Lam Research."We think the odds have significantly increased that Gigamon could be acquired," said Alex Henderson, a Needham analyst in a report. "We think a fair value is in the 50 to 55 range."Henderson went on to say: "We think Cisco Systems (CSCO), Juniper Networks (JNPR), F5, HPE, Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Fortinet (FTNT), Riverbed, and a number of private investors are likely to be among the names that would be interested in Gigamon."Gigamon competitors include Cisco, Ixia and NetScout (NTCT). In late 2016, Gigamon launched new products that enabled customers to use its products on Amazon.com's (AMZN) cloud-computing platform, Amazon Web Services.RELATED:Cisco 'Tetration' Data Center System Targets Gigamon NicheGigamon Talks Up Security, Amazon Public Cloud At Analyst Day

X Here's your Investing Action Plan for Wednesday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Despite a relatively slow, holiday-shortened week, actionable news may come from Analog Devices (ADI), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Semtech (SMTC). But the Federal Reserve's Beige Book of regional economic and business reports may overshadow quarterly reports as…

Thoughts from Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) management on how it plans to use growing cash on its balance sheet may overshadow earnings when it reports fiscal second-quarter results late Wednesday.It's the first earnings report since HPE spun off its enterprise services business, which merged with Computer Sciences to create DXC Technology (DXC). HPE expects to close the sale of its struggling software business to U.K.-based Micro Focus later this year."We believe that investors remain focused on how HPE can utilize their cash balance to make further transformative acquisitions to bolster growth and/or return excess capital to shareholders," said Katy Huberty, a Morgan Stanley analyst in a report.HPE in April updated its financial outlook to reflect the spinoff. Analysts estimate profit of 35 cents vs. 42 cents in the year-earlier period, with revenue falling 24% to $9.64 billion."HPE has missed consensus revenue estimates the last three quarters, most recently citing slower server demand and order cuts from a tier 1 service providers, rising component costs, and currency headwinds," added Huberty. "And while currency headwinds should be more muted this quarter, we believe that continued server and storage weakness, rising memory costs and more muted spending expectations with HPE will drive continued top-line weakness."HPE stock edged down 3 cents during early trading on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Amid its restructuring and uncertainty over how it'll use cash, HPE stock is trading at about the same price as six months ago.  Learn more about companies in the Computer-Tech Services group at IBD Stock Checkup.The Trump administration's proposal to lower taxes on overseas cash brought back to the U.S. could boost HPE as well as rival Cisco Systems (CSCO). But Trump's economic agenda has stalled.Silicon Valley pioneer Hewlett-Packard split into two publicly traded companies in November 2015, with its printer and PC business becoming HP Inc. (HPQ) HPE still sells networking, data storage and servers to corporate customers.RELATED:Overseas Tax Holiday For Tech Titans May Come With A CatchThis Top Software Firm Has Flipped From Losses: 220% EPS Gain Seen ThursdayCisco Sales Fall For Sixth Straight Quarter; Revenue Outlook Misses

Biotechs and software led a solid Nasdaq advance, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index hit record highs. Boeing (BA) announced a slew of Paris Air Show orders, while oil prices kept falling. The Fed cleared big banks in their annual stress tests while China cracked down on Weibo (WB). Amazon (AMZN) spooked more retailers.X The Nasdaq rose 1.8% for the week as biotechs and other medicals soared on eased fears about price controls and also in reaction to the Senate GOP health bill. Celgene (CELG) was among the biotech breakouts, while Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) soared out of buy range. Desktop software also was a big winner, with Oracle (ORCL) breaking out on earnings. Amazon fears intensified for apparel and sporting goods stories. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 index hit record highs Monday, but pared gains amid weakness in oil and retail stocks. The Dow finished fractionally higher while the S&P 500  rose 0.2%.Biotech stocks surged 10% this week as concerns that President Trump will tamp down on drug prices began to subside. Big winners in the rally included Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Celgene (CELG), which popped 12.5% and nearly 10%, respectively. Clovis Oncology (CLVS) spiked58% after strong trial data suggested a much-wider use for its ovarian cancer drug. Analysts called for "growth" stocks to gain the most and one sees the rally continuing another 15%.Traditional drug giants also fared well, with Novartis (NVS) breaking out to a buy point and Merck (MRK) nearing an entry.Boeing (BA) beat out Airbus (EADSY) on commercial jet orders at the 2017 Paris Air Show, an event typically won by the European aerospace giant. Boeing said it had "incremental orders and commitments" of 571 airplanes, valued at $74.8 billion at list prices. But analysts said "a staggering 64%" of Boeing's orders at the show weren't firm. Airbus said it booked firm orders of 144 planes valued at $18.5 billion and memorandums of understanding for 182 aircraft valued at $21.2 billion. Analysts weren't expecting many deals in Paris, but orders were double the $50 billion seen at last year's show in Farnborough, England. Boeing shares rose about 3% for the week, hitting new highs. Airbus set a record high Monday, but pared its weekly gain to 0.9%.RELATED: Why Boeing's Paris Air Show Orders Are 'Staggering''Hybrid' Design For New Boeing Midrange Jet Could Hit This Sweet SpotWhy Lockheed May Move F-16 Production To India From TexasOracle (ORCL) earnings easily topped views while revenue advanced 3% as the software giant's overall cloud revenue shot up 64% vs. a year earlier. Oracle had been a latecomer to the on-demand, cloud software shift but the transition is in full force now. Shares surged 13%, breaking out to a record high. Meanwhile, two other Software-Database leaders soared to record highs on stronger-than-expected earnings. Adobe Systems (ADBE) raised Q3 guidance after reporting a 44% EPS gain for its fiscal Q2. Red Hat (RHT) EPS climbed 12% in its fiscal Q1 while revenue rose 19%. The open-source Linux software provider also gave bullish current-quarter guidance. Adobe rose 5.5% while Red Hat climbed 13.2%.Crude oil prices fell to 10-month lows during the week amid continued oversupply concerns. Weekly U.S. crude stockpiles fell 2.45 million barrels, the Energy Information Administration said, double what was expected. But domestic crude production nudged up to 9.35 million barrels per day. Meanwhile, Libyan oil production rose sharply after a dispute ended with a German oil company. Exports from Nigeria are expected to hit 226,000 BPD in August vs. 164,000 BPD in July, according to Reuters. Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was appointed as heir to the kingdom's throne and is widely expected to continue current oil policies. He was a major force behind Riyadh's Saudi Vision 2030 reform initiative aimed at curbing the country's reliance on crude.RELATED:Oil Reverses Sharply Lower On Supply FearsJPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and the nation's biggest global banks would have enough capital to continue lending in an economic meltdown, the first round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress-results showed. None of the 34 banks tested had key capital levels below the minimum set by the Fed. But bank stocks generally edged lower Friday. Wall Street's attention will turn to results from the second portion of the exam that comes out on Wednesday. That portion will determine what the banks can give in buybacks and dividends and ultimately whether the firms pass or fail the tests on quantitative and qualitative grounds.JPMorgan, BofA, Goldman, Citi, Wells Fargo Pass Fed's Stress TestChina ordered Weibo (WB) and two other online platforms to shut down audiovisual streaming, presumably for user content that violated the country's political standards. Weibo tumbled 6.1% on Thursday, with majority-owner Sina Corp. (SINA), lost 4.8%. Alibaba (BABA), which owns a big minority stake in the Twitter (TWTR)-like Weibo, edged lower. Momo (MOMO) and YY (YY), two social media firms with a lot of streaming video, sold off initially but Momo closed up and YY pared losses. Sina, Momo and YY are all IBD 50 stocks.RELATED:Weibo Crackdown Spurs Selling, But Not Panic, In China InternetsAmazon struck fear in more retail groups, slamming many apparel and sporting goods chains. The e-commerce giant announced Amazon Prime Wardrobe, a home try-on system that lets users have three or more items shipped to them for free to try on at home, then be charged for what they keep. That hit Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), TJX (TJX) and more. Meanwhile, Bloomberg sources said Nike (NKE) would sell footwear directly on Amazon via a brand-registry program, sending shares of already-reeling Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Foot Locker (FL) and others sharply lower. But Finish Line (FINL) rebounded Friday despite mixed quarterly results.Meanwhile, Whole Foods Market (WFM) pushed a little further beyond the 42-a-share takeover price from Amazon, leading some to wonder if another bidder could be ready to emerge with an even bigger offer than $13.7 billion. Barclays said it "would not be surprised is there is a bidding war," and JPMorgan analysts have pegged Wal-Mart (WMT) as a possible contender. But Reuters reported late Friday that Wal-Mart is not planning a Whole Foods bid. Whole Foods closed the week up 0.6% at 42.94 after hitting 43.84 Friday afternoon.RELATED:Here's The Latest Group Having An Amazon-Induced Anxiety AttackPrime Wardrobe: Is This How Amazon Kills Macy's In Fashion Game?Uber Technologies founder Travis Kalanick resigned as chief executive officer following a shareholder revolt. The ride-hailing company had been exposed as having a workplace culture that included sexual harassment and discrimination. Uber also has been losing U.S. market share to Lyft.Twitter (TWTR) stock rose 11% as a bullish research report said the struggling company has improved its video strategy and execution. The report came on the same day Twitter announced a way for people to earn money by streaming live on its Periscope video service. Snapchat-operator Snap (SNAP) was under increased pressure from the Instagram Stories feature by Facebook (FB), which has grown to 250 million users, vs. 166 million for Snapchat. Snap is trading close to its IPO price of 17.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) surged nearly 24% for the week as it launched its latest server processors for data centers. AMD's new Epyc server chips will compete with processors from industry leader Intel (INTC). Joining AMD at a launch event in Austin, Texas, were customers and partners backing Epyc, including Microsoft (MSFT) Azure, Baidu (BIDU), Dell Technologies (DVMT) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE). Intel shares fell to a 2017 low.Shares of FedEx (FDX) rose 2.3% for the week, hitting a record high and moving out of buy range as the package delivery giant easily topped expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter Tuesday, shaking of EPS misses in the last two quarters. Earnings climbed 29% on a 21% jump in revenue to $15.7 billion. Investments to modernize its aircraft fleet and expand ground operations paid off, FedEx, while guiding full-year profit high. Rival UPS announced Monday that it will charge retailers an extra fee for holiday deliveries, while FedEx said it would consider that. Both shipping giants could be challenged as key customer Amazon (AMZN) expands its own delivery services.RELATED:FedEx Easily Tops Q4 Earnings, Revenue Forecasts; Guides Profit HighStrong SUV and truck sales helped to drive an across-the-board beat Wednesday for used-car superstore CarMax (KMX). First-quarter EPS climbed almost 26% year over year to $1.13 on a 10.1% rise in revenue to $4.54 billion. Total unit sales of used vehicles  jumped 14.1%. But even with large and medium SUVs and trucks accounting for a bigger share of the mix, the average used vehicle price fell 1.9% vs. a year earlier, accelerating from a 1.6% drop in the prior quarter. A flood of off-lease cars is hitting pricing, one reason while new-car sales are slumping. CarMax rose 1.7% in an up-and-down week.MSCI (MSCI) on Tuesday finally greenlighted the inclusion of mainland China stocks in its key emerging markets index. Wall Street had been closely watching the decision, since several funds — including the $32 billion iShares Emerging Markets ETF (EEM) — track or are benchmarked to that index. China's weight in the benchmark will jump to upward of 40% from the current 26%. The move surprised the markets; MSCI had given a red light to mainland stocks or "A shares" on three previous tries.EQT Corp. (EQT) agreed to buy Rice Energy (RICE) for around $6.7 billion. The deal, set to close in Q4, would create the U.S.' largest natural-gas producer and strengthen EQT's position in the Marcellus and Utica shale regions.Accenture (ACN) reported in-line fiscal Q3 profit and reported top-line growth slightly above views as new digital, cloud and security products and services reached 50% of revenue but management commentary on weakness in the health care market sent shares down.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) signaled that more acquisitions may be coming at its “Discover” customer conference this week, say analysts.There’s been speculation that Hewlett Packard Enterprise could acquire an enterprise software company or F5 Networks (FFIV), a supplier of data center gear.Katy Huberty, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, says Hewlett Packard Enterprise’s recent acquisitions have turned out well."While the company is focused on organic innovation, HPE is open to acquisitions similar to 3Par, 3Com and Aruba -- complimentary technologies that can be sold through HP's distribution channel,” Huberty said in a report. “Software-defined and hyperconverged products are a key area of focus with acquisitions potentially focused here.”At Jefferies, analyst James Kisner says Hewlett Packard Enterprise could be in the hunt for Seattle-based F5 Networks. (F5 Networks shot up nearly 13% on Tuesday on a report that it had hired Goldman Sachs (GS) to help review takeover approaches.)“From a strategic perspective, we believe HPE could be a possible suitor,” said Kisner in a report. “HPE’s Aruba acquisition has been doing well. At Discover, (CEO Meg) Whitman noted that the size of potential acquisitions is less of an issue than their valuation. We note that F5 is trading at a similar valuation as Aruba pre-acquisition.”Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz has an underweight rating on Hewlett Packard Enterprise."The Discover customer conference highlighted management confidence in GDP-like revenue growth as the company invests outside the data center in the $25B campus/edge market and machine learning," wrote Moskowitz in a report. "HPE exhibited some flexibility on M&A, as there was commentary suggesting acquisitions can be pursued if done at the right multiples. Given the successes of Aruba, 3PAR, and ArcSight, we think HPE’s M&A track record has enough support to pursue a larger acquisition if it can move the revenue needle."Hewlett Packard Enterprise on May 25 said it would spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), a move that could put pressure on IBM (IBM) to respond, analysts say.HP Enterprise shares finished 1% higher on the stock market today, hitting a record high for a fourth straight day.

F5 Networks (FFIV) stock pulled back Wednesday, a day after shares in the data center gear maker surged 13% to a 10-month high near 125, on a report that the company is up for sale.If Seattle-based F5 Networks goes on the block, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) looms as a possible buyer, says a Citigroup report, though it's not the only possibility on the investment bank's radar.“We see potential buyers as Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Dell, EMC (EMC), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and private equity,” Citigroup analyst Jim Suva wrote in a research report. Privately held broad-based tech provider Dell is set to complete its acquisition of storage systems giant EMC any day now.F5, the leading maker of application delivery controllers — electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers -- has at various times over the years been considered a possible takeover target. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.F5 stock fell 2.9% to 120.35 in the stock market today.Hewlett Packard Enterprise plans to spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), a move that could pressure IBM (IBM) to respond, analysts say.The former Hewlett-Packard Inc. in November completed its split-up into Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which focuses on enterprise hardware, software and services, and HP Inc., which focuses on the PC and printer businesses.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock rose 1% to 19.35 Wednesday, touching a record high for the third straight day. IBM advanced 0.4% and Cisco Systems rose 0.2% while EMC dipped 0.2%.
