Cisco Systems (CSCO) late Wednesday reported fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue that topped Wall Street views and raised its quarterly dividend by 12%, but shares slipped after hours.Cisco hiked its quarterly dividend by 3 cents, to 29 cents, up 12%. In fiscal 2016, Cisco increased its dividend by 24%.Cisco said it earned 57 cents per share minus items, flat from the year-earlier period but topping views by a penny. Revenue for the quarter ended Jan. 28 fell 2% to $11.58 billion, but that beat expectations of $11.55 billion. Some of the sales decline stems from Cisco's sale of its set-top-box business last year. Even so, Cisco's year-over-year sales fell for the fifth straight quarter.In the current quarter, Cisco forecast EPS of 58 cents, in line with consensus estimates, and a 1% revenue drop at the midpoint of its guidance to roughly $11.78 billion. Analysts had projected $11.86 billion in revenue.In fiscal Q2, Cisco said it repurchased 33 million shares of its own common stock for $1 billion.IBD'S TAKE: Cisco's dividend yield is higher than those of Intel, Microsoft and Apple. While telecoms have been favorites of investors looking for high dividends, there are other options, such as banks, industrials and real estate investment trusts (REITs). Check out IBD's Income Investor for high-dividend-paying stocks.Cisco shares were down 0.7% in after-hours trading in the stock market today following its earnings release. Cisco stock rose 1.6% to 32.82 in Wednesday's regular session. Cisco on Tuesday climbed above a 32.05 buy point and is trading at more than nine-year highs.Cisco has been shifting to software and services from its core business of selling network switches and routers. Cisco in January said it would acquire software provider AppDynamics for $3.7 billion.Cisco has about $69 billion of cash on its balance sheet, with just over $60 billion of that overseas. The Trump administration has proposed a one-time tax cut for the repatriation of U.S. companies' corporate profits held overseas, which could provide Cisco with more ammunition to make acquisitions or hike dividends.RELATED:Cisco Systems Requires 'Needle-Moving' M&A, Says AnalystHow Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPECould Microsoft Join Cisco In Hunt For Security Firms?

Cisco Systems' (CSCO) acquisition of AppDynamics for $3.7 billion sparked takeover speculation of other software companies, with shares of New Relic (NEWR) and Splunk (SPLK) both surging Wednesday.Cisco late Tuesday snapped up AppDynamics just before it was set to be the first big tech IPO — the first tech unicorn IPO — of 2017. New Relic stock rose 11% to 36.85 in the stock market today, earlier hitting 40.10, just below a record high for a company that went public in 2014 at 23.Splunk stock rose 7.6% Wednesday, hitting a nearly two-month high and rising above both its 50-day and 200-day lines for the first time since early this month.Cisco stock edged up 0.33% Wednesday.AppDynamics provides cloud-based software that measures and analyzes the performance of business critical applications."The acquisition broadens Cisco's software portfolio as Cisco attempts to diversify its revenue base with more subscription and recurring revenue," said Alex Kurtz, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, in a research report. "The traditional market for application performance management (APM) is roughly $4 billion, but analytics, the shift to cloud deployments and the consolidation of monitoring tools appears to be expanding the addressable market."Other vendors with APM exposure include Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and NetScout Systems (NTCT). We believe there is a split in the market between the next-generation players, with AppDynamics tending more toward hybrid cloud deployments and New Relic toward public cloud and digital deployments."IBD'S TAKE: Seacoast Banking, Inphi, GrubHub and NetEase are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. AppDynamics, which recently raised the target range of its IPO to $12-$14 a share from $10-$12, was expected to price Wednesday night and begin trading on Thursday. The software maker had targeted a maximum valuation of $1.7 billion.AppDynamics will operate as a unit in Cisco's IoT division.Splunk is an AppDynamics rival and some have said it's also been eyed by Cisco, Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard said in a research note. He says those rumors likely will cool after Cisco's announcement."We think Splunk and AppDynamics fight for budget in some customer projects and we expect the intensity of this would increase or decrease depending on how Cisco executes in integration and its leverage of AppDynamics offerings across broader distribution channel," Pritchard wrote. "Some had viewed Cisco as a potential acquirer of Splunk and while SPLK and AppDynamics are somewhat complementary, we expect investor sentiment around a Cisco/Splunk combination to cool."In any case, a host of software mergers could be in the offing, analysts say."We expected 2017 to be a better year for software M&A, and we certainly got off to a strong start with this transaction," RBC Capital analyst Matthew Hedberg said in a report. "In addition to AppDynamics, other market leaders in the APM space include New Relic and privately-held Dynatrace as well as challengers including CA Technologies (CA), IBM (IBM), Hewlett Packard Enterprises, BMC Software and Riverbed."Ittai Kidron, an analyst at Oppenheimer, said: "We're mixed on the Cisco acquisition's impact on New Relic. Positively, it suggests meaningful valuation upside and could put NEWR into play (potentially IBM or another legacy APM vendor). It also could create some execution distraction at AppDynamics."RELATED:Cisco Systems Nabs AppDynamics For $3.7 Billion, Just Before IPO

Cash-rich Cisco Systems (CSCO) reports earnings for its fiscal Q2 ended Jan. 28 after the close Wednesday, after a stock breakout Tuesday and with analysts expecting management will comment on profit margins, revenue growth, M&A and shareholder returns amid the companies continuing shift to software and services from its core business of selling network switches and routers.Analysts estimate EPS of 56 cents, down a penny from the year-earlier period, on revenue of $11.55 billion, down 3%. Some of the sales decline stems from Cisco's sale of its set-top box business.Cisco, with its stock hitting a buy point Tuesday and trading at more than nine-year highs, continues to make acquisitions, including its January announcement that it would acquire software provider AppDynamics for $3.7 billion.For the current quarter, analysts estimate EPS of 58 cents, up a penny from last year's April quarter, and revenue of $11.85 billion, down less than 1%, for the No. 1 maker of networking gear.IBD'S TAKE: Weibo, Netflix, Tesla and Alibaba are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping."We think sentiment is largely tepid as investors anticipate muted top-line results with EPS numbers that may come down a tad due to the AppDynamics purchase," said Mitch Steves, an RBC Capital analyst, in a research report.A year ago, Cisco hiked its dividend by 24%. Cisco's dividend yield is higher than dividends offered by such companies as Intel (INTC) Microsoft (MSFT) and Apple (AAPL).Cisco's market-share losses in network switching have accelerated, mainly to competition from Arista Networks (ANET). An earnings call topic could be whether Cisco plans to step up acquisitions in data center infrastructure or security. The latter now accounts for 5% of revenue.Cisco has about $69 billion of cash on its balance sheet, with just over $60 billion of that overseas. The Trump administration has proposed a one-time tax cut for the repatriation of U.S. companies' corporate profits held overseas, which could provide Cisco with more ammunition to make acquisitions or hike dividends.Cisco stock rose 1% to 32.30 in the stock market today, touching a buy point of 32.04 out of a 16-week flat base. Shares are at their highest point since November 2007.RELATED:Cisco Systems Requires 'Needle-Moving' M&A, Says AnalystHow Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPECould Microsoft Join Cisco In Hunt For Security Firms?

Hewlett Packard Enterprise's (HPE) acquisition of  SimpliVity for $650 million in cash will create a stronger rival to Nutanix (NTNX), the leader in the budding "hyperconverged" data center  infrastructure market, as well as with Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Dell Technologies (DVMT), the merged Dell and EMC, analysts say.HPE said late Tuesday it would buy privately held SimpliVity.Both Nutanix and SimpliVity sell software that manages network, storage and server infrastructure in private cloud platforms, an emerging market called "hyperconvergence." Most of their revenue comes from specialized appliances, but the market is shifting to software that runs on low-cost servers."Strategically, we believe that this transaction makes sense as it jump-starts HPE's entry into the HCI space and likely allows for substantial revenue and cost synergies," said James Kisner, a Jefferies analyst, in a research report.IBD'S TAKE:  Nutanix went public at 16 per share on Sept. 30, raising $238 million. The stock peaked in its second day of trading, at 46.78, but swooned in the latter half on 2016. But Nutanix stock has gained 15% this year. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup. HPE estimates that the hyperconverged market was $2.4 billion in 2016 and is expected to reach  about $6 billion by 2020.HPE stock ended trading up 0.8% to close at 22.86 on the stock market today. Nutanix fell 6.3% to 28.17. Nutanix went public at 16 in September. It has an IBD Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A-, indicating institutions have been buying than selling.In March 2015, SimpliVity raised $175 million at a $1 billion valuation, but big companies, including Dell/EMC and HPE have pushed into the market."Given the down-tick in valuation, it seems possible the vendor (SimpliVity) may have seen a significant slowdown in its growth rate," Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard said in his report.An RBC Capital analyst says Nutanix has market momentum."We don't think this transaction disrupts Nutanix's momentum, and in fact, it further validates the market," RBC's Matthew Hedberg said in his research report. "We think Nutanix (52% market share) was winning more than its fair share of business against both HPE (3% market share) and SimpliVity (18% market share) independently, and bringing the two companies together likely does little to change Nutanix's win rates."RELATED:Cisco, HPE Rival Nutanix Posts Q1 Beat, But Stock FallsTech Unicorn Nutanix Embraced With Positive Coverage Post-IPO

Shares of software developer Hortonworks (HDP) jumped as much as 14% Friday, following the company's fourth-quarter earnings report late Thursday that topped expectations.Hortonworks reported revenue of $52 million, topping the consensus estimate of $48 million and up 39% year over year. It posted a per-share loss minus items of 50 cents, but analysts had modeled a 60-cent loss. It lost 72 cents a share in the year-earlier quarter.In the stock market today, Hortonworks stock rose 4.7% to 10.65. But earlier it rose as high as 11.59, just triggering a sell rule because that put the stock up 20% from its Jan. 30 breakout at 9.65.Hortonworks, though, is trading well below its December 2014 initial public offering price of 16. The company is a developer of Hadoop open-source software, which companies can use to better manage so-called Big Data.IBD'S TAKE: Hortonworks is trading above its 200-day and 50-day moving average, a positive indicator, though it sports a weak IBD Composite Rating of 29. For a look at growth stocks, check out the IBD 50 listing.For Q1, Hortonworks estimates revenue of $52 million and a 53-cent per-share loss ex items, both matching the consensus estimate.Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White maintained a buy rating on Hortonworks stock, with a price target of 21."After a difficult start to 2016 that continued with a much weaker than expected earnings report last August, Hortonworks has gotten its stride back with two consecutive quarters of solid results," White wrote in a research note. "Not only is Hortonworks executing better but the company is pushing more aggressively into the cloud and newer products are starting to show strong momentum."Needham analyst Richard Kugele maintained a hold rating on Hortonworks but did not assign a price target."The gradual recovery underway at Hortonworks over the past couple quarters continued with the company posting a solid O4," Kugele wrote in a research note.RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPE

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is at a crossroads and should make "needle-moving" acquisitions either in data-center infrastructure, software or security, says a William Blair analyst."We do not believe the old Cisco playbook of numerous tuck-in acquisitions combined with a few larger bets in emerging product areas will work," said Jason Ader, a William Blair analyst, in a research report Monday. He maintained an outperform rating on Cisco stock, which inched down 2 cents to 31.30 on the stock market today, close to a buy point of 32.04.If Cisco "doubles down" on data-center infrastructure, Ader speculates, it could buy Nutanix (NTNX), Pure Storage (PSTG), Nimble Storage (NMBL) or NetApp (NTAP).If Cisco takes a "hard pivot" toward software, it could acquire Splunk (SPLK), Red Hat (RHT) or ServiceNow (NOW), Ader said.Cisco now garners about 5% of revenue from computer security products. It could make a big jump by purchasing Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) or Proofpoint (PFPT), Ader added."Like its large-cap peers in IT infrastructure, we believe Cisco needs to embark on a fundamental business metamorphosis," Ader said in the report.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix, Glaukos and Broadcom are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Cisco in January agreed to buy AppDynamics for $3.7 billion, just ahead of that company's planned IPO. AppDynamics provides cloud-based software that measures and analyzes the performance of business critical applications.While Cisco has a partnership with Dell-EMC on networking products,  Ader says it could "file for a full divorce."Ader says that Cisco's effort to build a cloud computing rival to Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), hasn't clicked. "Its much-hyped, $1 billion Intercloud cloud-federation project launched in 2015 is expected to be shuttered shortly — likely another casualty of AWS," wrote Ader.The Trump administration has proposed a one-time tax cut for the repatriation of U.S. companies' corporate profits held overseas, which could provide Cisco with more ammunition to make acquisitions, says the William Blair analyst."We believe the company needs to place needle-moving M&A bets with a clear strategic objective, instead of its current (incremental) approach," he wrote.RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPE

Symantec (SYMC) late Wednesday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views but forecast current-quarter sales and profit below expectations, sending shares in the security software maker down after hours.Symantec said fiscal Q3 earnings minus items rose 23% from the year-earlier quarter to 32 cents. Revenue climbed 20% to $1.09 billion for the three months ended Dec. 30.Analysts had projected non-GAAP profit of 28 cents and $1.08 billion in revenue.In the current quarter, Symantec forecast profit of 28 cents, up 27%, and $1.08 billion in sales, up 25%, at the midpoint of its guidance range, vs. consensus estimates of 29 cents and $1.1 billion.Mountain View, Calif.-based Symantec stock was down 3% in after-hours trading in the stock market today, following the company's earnings release. Shares fell 1% to 27.25 in the regular session Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Revenue growth is harder to come by for security vendors these days. Chipmaker Nvidia, which tops the IBD 50 roster of growth stocks, reports earnings on Feb. 9. Inphi, a member of IBD's Sector Leaders, reports on Feb. 7.Symantec acquired Blue Coat Systems in 2016 for $4.65 billion. Blue Coat Chief Executive Greg Clark became Symantec's CEO in August. Symantec in November announced it would acquire LifeLock, a provider of identity-theft protection services, for $2.3 billion.John DiFucci, an analyst at investment bank Jefferies, says Symantec might revise guidance when the LifeLock deal closes.Symantec sells security software to both businesses and consumers. Analysts say the LifeLock deal is aimed at bolstering its Norton security unit.Symantec's anti-virus software is often bundled with PCs. The Blue Coat acquisition put Symantec in the fast-growing cloud-access security broker market. CASB products act as a middleman between a corporate network and cloud applications hosted externally.Symantec on Wednesday also announced a $1 billion debt offering. Although Symantec will have some $8 billion in debt when the LifeLock deal closes, analysts say Symantec's acquisition spree could go on. Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) are also viewed as companies that could be looking to make acquisitions.IBD's Computer-Software Security group ranks No. 148 out of 197 industry groups. Fortinet (FTNT) and FireEye (FEYE) report earnings after the market close Thursday.RELATED:

Could Salesforce.com Buy Microsoft Rival Slack Technologies?How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPECheck Point Price Target Hiked On Consolidation ThemeCould Microsoft Join Cisco In Hunt For Security Firms?Cisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift

Hot startup and Microsoft (MSFT) rival Slack Technologies is pushing into the enterprise market, a move that will be closely watched by rivals and potential acquirers like Salesforce.com (CRM) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).Slack and its business messenger app have been valued at more than $3.8 billion, so the company is among the tech unicorns — startups valued at $1 billion-plus. Slack says it has more than 4 million daily active users, with 1.25 million paid.Slack on Monday said it's developing a new version of its communications software for large companies. Slack's team chat app has been popular with businesses with fewer than 100 employees.Microsoft is creating a new office chat app that competes with Slack, while Cisco reportedly also has a rival technology in the works. Microsoft aims to integrate its app with Office 365.IBD'S TAKE: Microsoft is trading near record highs. For a look at companies hitting 52-week highs, listed according to Composite Ratings, regularly check IBD's New Highs list.While Microsoft mulled an offer for Slack before buying LinkedIn last year, Slack makes a good fit for Salesforce.com, says Andrew Bartel, a principal analyst at Forrester Research."Slack would make sense for Salesforce.com," said Bartel. "Slack is a competitor to Microsoft Office. It would put Salesforce into a new category of communications software."The Microsoft-Salesforce rivalry has been heating up.Slack has said it would not consider an IPO before 2018. Slack's chat app replaces emails by setting up textual conversations among groups involved in team projects.Slack in late 2016 partnered with Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), which is integrating the chat app with its G Suite cloud collaboration software.Salesforce.com doled out more than $4.6 billion in 2016 making acquisitions, including its $2.8 billion the purchase of e-commerce firm Demandware, which helps companies run their online shopping sites. Salesforce.com backed away from making an offer for Twitter (TWTR).Cisco in January acquired AppDynamics for $3.7 billion, sparking takeover speculation of other software companies, such as New Relic (NEWR) and Splunk (SPLK). AppDynamics provides cloud-based software that measures and analyzes the performance of business critical applications.Shares of Salesforce dipped 0.7% to close at 78.58 in the stock market today. Cisco lost 0.8% to 30.49. Both are relatively close to buy points. Salesforce stock moved up its 200-day moving average in mid-January and is eyeing a buy point of 84.58. Cisco has formed a flat base with a buy point of 32.04.RELATED:Will Microsoft Stymie Salesforce.com's Stock Turnaround?How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPE

ServiceNow's (NOW) Q4 beat-and-raise late Wednesday won at least six price-target hikes for the stock, which broke out Thursday, gapping up to a record high.ServiceNow jumped as much as 7.7% in the stock market today to a high of 92.98, ending the day at 89.48, up 3.6%.The enterprise software provider late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter non-GAAP profit and revenue that topped Wall Street views, as did its current-quarter and full-year revenue guidance.RBC Capital hiked its price target to 108 from 95, Citigroup to 107 from 95, BMO Capital Markets to 104 from 97, Mizuho to 100 from 90, FBN Securities to 110 from 105, and UBS to 101 from 93."We don't believe any other company in our high-growth universe is showing this strong growth at scale in core and such a ramp in new products," Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard said in a research report. "At the same time, the ability to continue margin ramp is also unmatched."We believe this is testament to culture of strong execution, making the right product choices and also the fortune of a benign competitive landscape."IBD'S TAKE: With Thursday's gain, ServiceNow stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base and leapt into a buy zone, climbing past a buy point of 89.89 in high volume. Learn more on ServiceNow's growth trends at IBD Stock Checkup.ServiceNow's core business is software for information technology service management, or ITSM. ServiceNow has expanded into human resources, customer service and security software.ServiceNow's push into new markets has heated up competition with Salesforce.com (CRM), which has been viewed as a possible buyer. Other rivals include CA Technologies  (CA)  and Hewlett Packard Enterprise  (HPE). ServiceNow has a new partnership with IBM (IBM)."ServiceNow is operating at a very high level as the flywheel of a true multiproduct platform company accelerates," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a report. "Billings easily beat expectations and accelerated due in part to strong large deal activity, strong cross sell and high renewal rates."ServiceNow said Q4 profit minus items rose 26% year over year to 24 cents a share, as revenue jumped 37% to $392 million. Analysts had expected EPS of 23 cents and revenue of $379 million.For the current quarter, ServiceNow forecast revenue of $406 million to $411 million, up 33% to 34%. Analysts had projected $403 million. For the year, ServiceNow forecast revenue of $1.82 to $1.85 billion vs. consensus estimates of $1.8 billion.Piper Jaffray analyst Alex Zukin maintained a neutral rating on the stock, citing its steep climb of late. ServiceNow stock is up 22% in 2017."While we believe that the company is well-positioned to execute on its goal of $4 billion in revenue in 2020, we would remain sidelined at current valuation levels pending a better entry point," Zukin said in his research report.RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPESalesforce.com Stock Rallies In 2017 As Top Software Pick

Initial jobless claims fell by 5,000 last week to 267,000, the Labor Department said Thursday. The four-week average rose by 1,750 to 272,500, a three-month high.But by either measure, unemployment filings have held below 300,000 for almost the entire year, hitting a long-term low in July. Sub-300,000 readings normally signal booming job gains, but not in this economic cycle.Net job growth has been mediocre. Yes, there have been layoffs. Hewlett-Packard, now split into HP Inc. (HPQ) and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE), announced plans to cut 30,000 workers. Oil services firms Schlumberger (SLB), Halliburton (HAL) and Baker Hughes (BHI) have announced tens of thousands of job cuts as demand plunges with the price of crude.But jobless claims and layoffs aren't the culprit. The problem is that actual gross hiring — hiring before any job cuts or exits — still hasn't returned to pre-recession levels, according to Labor's JOLTS report. Truth be told, gross hiring wasn't booming in the prior 2001-2007 expansion either, so failing to live up even to that pace isn't encouraging.Weak gross hiring likely is one reason why the labor force participation rate, including among prime-age workers, remains so low. Weak hiring — and firing — also suggest a less-dynamic economy. Some labor market churn is good, as workers move to more-productive jobs and industries.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter @IBD_ECarson and on Facebook.

IBM reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday, and its CEO said it's making "significant progress" in a major company transition, but 2016 EPS guidance fell short of analyst expectations.

IBM (IBM) reported revenue of $22.06 billion, down 8.5% from the year-earlier quarter but slightly edging the Wall Street consensus estimate of $22 billion. Adjusting for currency exchange rates, IBM said revenue fell 2%.
The company has been hit by currency-exchange woes, as IBM derives a majority of its revenue from offshore markets.
It reported earnings per share ex items of $4.84, topping views by 3 cents but down 17% — its third quarter in a row of EPS declines.
It was the 15th quarter in a row of year-over-year revenue declines.
For 2016, the company expects EPS ex items of $13.50, well short of the $14.97 analysts had modeled. IBM didn't give other guidance.
IBM stock was down 3% in after-hours trading following the company's Q4 earnings. In the regular session, IBM stock fell 1.5% to 128.11 and touched its lowest price since September 2010.
IBM stock has been in retreat since hitting its all-time high of 215.90 in March 2013.

Big Blue has long been in transition, shedding hardware units and realigning its workforce to reduce costs as it focuses on cloud computing, Big Data analytics, security and mobile computing — growth areas it calls strategic imperatives.

IBM said revenue from strategic imperatives rose 17% in 2015 to $29 billion, compared with a 12% decline in overall revenue from continuing operations, to $81.7 billion. Strategic imperatives now comprise 35% of total revenue.
In its investor conference last February, IBM had said that it expected its strategic imperatives revenue to rise about 20% in 2015.
Tuesday, the company said Q4 revenue from strategic imperatives rose 10%, or 16% adjusting for currency.
Transforming To 'Higher Value'

"We continue to make significant progress in our transformation to higher value," IBM CEO Ginni Rometty said in the company's earnings release. "We strengthened our existing portfolio while investing aggressively in new opportunities like Watson Health, Watson Internet of Things and hybrid cloud."
For 2015, IBM said total cloud revenue, including public, private and hybrid, rose 43% (up 57% adjusting for currency and its divested System X business) to $10.2 billion.

Revenues for cloud delivered as a service — a subset of the total cloud revenue — increased 50% to $4.5 billion. Revenue from business analytics rose 7% (16% adjusting for currency) to $17.9 billion. It said revenue from mobile more than tripled, and security revenue rose 5%.

In a conference call with the media after its earnings release, company CFO Martin Schroeter said IBM will continue into invest in strategic imperatives to drive its transformation. He said IBM spent $6 billion on research and development in 2015. In addition, it spent $3 billion to acquire 14 companies, half in the cloud market.
"We've maintained high levels of investments and see returns from them," Schroeter said.

IBM isn't the only long-time, or legacy, tech vendor amid a major transition. Other tech giants amid transition and struggling for growth include Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), Oracle (ORCL), EMC (EMC) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).

"Over the past year, growth has been like watching grass grow as these large, traditional informational technology vendors face a Kilimanjaro-like climb in their quest for success in this ever-changing IT landscape," wrote FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research note last week.

As evidenced by Dell's planned acquisition of EMC, "these once almighty stalwarts are now scratching their heads trying to figure out the path for a renaissance of growth around cloud, Big Data, cybersecurity and the Internet of Things," Ives wrote.
IBM has said it will plow $3 billion over the next four years into its Internet of Things unit.

Closing the book on the 76-year legacy of Hewlett-Packard Co., Meg Whitman continued with Volume II Tuesday by chairing both successor companies and disclosing that the former company's final Q4 earnings missed Wall Street projections.
But she also guided one of the successor company's fiscal 2016 forecasts higher than Wall Street estimates.
Thus, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock was up 2.5% in after-hours trading, after the earnings release.

As of the Nov. 1 start of the fiscal year, Hewlett-Packard Co. split into two separate companies, HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer business, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which sells systems and provides services for businesses and other enterprise clients.
Whitman is CEO of HPE.
Hewlett-Packard Co. earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise segment sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion, but was up 3% in constant currency, the company said. It was the second consecutive quarter of year-to-year constant currency revenue growth, the company said.
Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post pro forma Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion in Q4.
Analysts also estimated that it would earn 52 cents per share minus items in Q4.

The Enterprise company reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.

"Hewlett Packard Enterprise is off to a very strong start," said Whitman in the earnings release. "The new company's business segments delivered a second consecutive quarter of constant currency revenue growth in Q4, and we believe that momentum will accelerate into fiscal '16."

Analysts and investors are still focused on "management's thoughts on the overall IT spending environment, cloud initiatives, restructuring/cost-cutting initiatives, and importantly comments around (Hewlett Packard Enterprise's) M&A strategy and how this could affect the rest of the tech space in 2016 and beyond," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a pre-release research note.Closing the book on the 76-year legacy of Hewlett-Packard Co., Meg Whitman continued with Volume II Tuesday by chairing both successor companies and disclosing that the former company's final Q4 earnings missed Wall Street projections.But she also guided one of the successor company's fiscal 2016 forecasts higher than Wall Street estimates.Thus, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock was up 2.5% in after-hours trading, after the earnings release.As of the Nov. 1 start of the fiscal year, Hewlett-Packard Co. split into two separate companies, HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer business, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which sells systems and provides services for businesses and other enterprise clients.Whitman is CEO of HPE.Hewlett-Packard Co. earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Hewlett Packard Enterprise segment sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion, but was up 3% in constant currency, the company said. It was the second consecutive quarter of year-to-year constant currency revenue growth, the company said.Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post pro forma Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion in Q4.Analysts also estimated that it would earn 52 cents per share minus items in Q4.The Enterprise company reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion."Hewlett Packard Enterprise is off to a very strong start," said Whitman in the earnings release. "The new company's business segments delivered a second consecutive quarter of constant currency revenue growth in Q4, and we believe that momentum will accelerate into fiscal '16."Analysts and investors are still focused on "management's thoughts on the overall IT spending environment, cloud initiatives, restructuring/cost-cutting initiatives, and importantly comments around (Hewlett Packard Enterprise's) M&A strategy and how this could affect the rest of the tech space in 2016 and beyond," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a pre-release research note.

It should be among the most unusual earnings conference calls in corporate history — certainly in Hewlett Packard Enterprise's (HPE) history, which by the time the company reports after the close Tuesday will have gone back, oh, 24 days since it became a company, though it's also 76 years old and could claim to be the pioneering Silicon Valley tech outfit.Reporting its fiscal Q4, which ended Oct. 31, Meg Whitman will hold court as both the new chairwoman and chief executive of Hewlett Packard Enterprise and as the continuing chairwoman and former chair and CEO of the former Hewlett-Packard, now known as HP Inc. (HPQ).HP Inc. kept the former Hewlett-Packard's ticker, HPQ. Hewlett Packard Enterprise got a new ticker, HPE.HP Inc. keeps the legacy computers and printer businesses. Hewlett Packard Enterprise takes the more ephemeral but — some analysts say — more promising enterprise services and cloud-enabled technologies businesses.In the past week, investors bid up Enterprise stock 6%, and 3% on Friday alone, to 14.21. That was its second best day of the month but still 5.5% off its open Nov. 2.Q4 might also be known as a clean-up quarter, a place to book some of the losses and charges related to the restructuring. Whitman said in September that the reorganization will impact cash by about $2.6 billion over three years starting in the current year, its fiscal 2016."These restructuring activities will enable a more competitive, sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise," Whitman said in September. "We've done a significant amount of work over the past few years to take costs out and simplify processes, and these final actions will eliminate the need for any future corporate restructuring."Cost savings are coming, in part, from the elimination of as many as 30,000 jobs from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, three years after the old, combined Hewlett-Packard cut 55,000 jobs. At the time of the September Q3 earnings release, the combined company had about 302,000 jobs.For Q4 2015, the old Hewlett-Packard estimated that EPS minus items for the entire company would range from 92 to 98 cents. The estimate excludes 80 cents in separation costs and other charges.Analysts ascribed more than half of that income, 52 cents, to the future Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Thomson Reuters analysts estimated Q4 revenue at $13.5 billion.For Q1, ending Jan. 31, analysts expect Enterprise to earn 44 cents per share, minus items, on $12.77 billion in revenue.In Q3, ended July 31, the old Enterprise Group sales rose 2%, with a 13% operating margin, the old company said."While we have to wait for HP's Q4 results to see the first full post-split balance-sheet details, HPE's filings disclose a pro-forma cash and investment position totaled approximately $11.5 billion exiting Q3," wrote Stifel analyst Aaron Rakers in a research report. "HPE's total debt position stands at (about) $16 billion; however, it is important to note that this includes about $10.6 billion on HP Financial Services debt. This leaves HPE net operating cash at approximately $5.5 billion exiting Q3 (excluding about $615 million of reported HPFS cash)."We would note that prior conversations have suggested that HPE will be focused on maintaining an investment-grade debt rating or a debt-to-EBITDA in the 2.0x-2.5x range."We expect investors to focus on HPE's capacity to make strategic acquisitions."Stifel initiated Hewlett Packard Enterprise with a hold rating.

Looking to push the legacy (i.e. old) giant tech stalwarts to use their cash piles to buy their way into faster growth, FBR analyst Daniel Ives issued a research report Thursday that praised Microsoft (MSFT) for its transition but kicked others — Cisco Systems, Oracle, IBM and Hewlett Packard — for their "treadmill approach" to expansion.And then he issued a wish-list of his top 10 tech tie-ups for 2016."It has been a choppy environment for tech players with a very bipolar IT spending backdrop," Ives said. "On the large-cap front, we have seen many changes from the HP split (into HP Inc. (HPQ) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to the largest tech merger ever in Dell/EMC (EMC)."Dell offered $67 billion in October to buy EMC."That said, it has been a tough road for many of these traditional tech stalwarts such as Oracle (ORCL), IBM (IBM), Cisco (CSCO) and HP, as investors have gotten used to seeing lackluster growth on a quarterly basis in light of the massive secular and company-specific challenges these mature tech vendors face," Ives said."The lone bright star in this cloudy large-cap enterprise tech space has been Microsoft, which is gaining momentum into 2016, as (CEO Satya) Nadella has made some tough decisions ('ripping the Band-Aid' off Nokia, cost cutting, free Windows 10 download strategy) to put (Microsoft) on the yellow brick road to the cloud."We believe the combination of the Dell/EMC deal, Amazon (AMZN) (Web Services') laser focus on the cloud and Nadella's 'golden child' success has put more heat in the kitchen for CEOs such as (IBM CEO Ginni) Rometty, (HPE CEO Meg) Whitman, (Oracle co-CEOs Safra Catz and Mark Hurd), and (Cisco CEO Chuck) Robbins to change from their 'treadmill approach' heading into 2016 and to focus on M&A and/or organic growth initiatives."FBR's top 10 merger-and-acquisition wish list for 2016, "in no particular order," Ives said, are:• (1) Cisco and NetApp (NTAP),• (2) Cisco and FireEye (FEYE),• (3) IBM and Splunk (SPLK),• (4) IBM and Qlik Technologies (QLIK),• (5) HPE and Box (BOX),• (6) HPE and Qlik,• (7) Oracle and Verint (VRNT),• (8) Oracle and NetSuite (N),• (9) Microsoft and Imperva (IMPV), and• (10) Microsoft and Qualys (QLYS)."... we believe EMC/Dell has disrupted the landscape and will force many of these mature tech stalwarts to finally be more aggressive in 2016 instead of fretting about valuations, as they need to focus on putting fuel back in their near-empty growth tanks," Ives said.

Proofpoint (PFPT) is expected to swing to a profit when it reports Q4 earnings after the market close Thursday, with the security software maker's revenue expected to jump 40% to $104.8 million.Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Proofpoint, which is near a breakout, is expected to earn 13 cents per share vs. an 11-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Its year-over-year revenue would decline from 44% in Q3, but the company has posted sales gains between 33% and 46% for the past 12 quarters.Proofpoint stock closed up 1.35% to 80.80 in the stock market today, nearing a buy point of 82.81 out of a cup-with-handle pattern.Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Proofpoint specializes in email and data loss protection for corporate networks and cloud-computing infrastructure. Its software spots malware-ridden emails before they arrive in inboxes.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer-Software Security group is ranked a poor No. 154 out of 197 industry groups, but it could perk up with M&A activity. Check Point Software Technologies and CyberArk Software have the group's highest Composite Ratings. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, analysts estimate non-GAAP profit of 5 cents and revenue of $107.7 million, vs. a 9-cent loss and sales of $79 million in Q1 2016."2017 revenue guidance has already been provided at 29% to 30%, as we expect that to move slightly higher," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a research report.Proofpoint's software provides email protection for Microsoft's (MSFT) cloud-based Office 365 productivity toolsProofpoint competes with Cisco Systems  (CSCO), Symantec (SYMC), Trend Micro and others. It has partnerships with Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Splunk (SPLK).RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPEProofpoint 'Continues To Separate From Security Pack' As Q3 BeatsCisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift

ServiceNow's (NOW) push into new markets is expected to boost Q4 revenue, with analysts estimating sales growth of nearly 33%, with non-GAAP EPS rising 15%.The enterprise software provider reports fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday."Q4 represents the next leg of what we still see as a compelling second-half 2016 setup, with the easiest billings comparison of 2016 and estimates for quarter-over-quarter subscription revenue growth," said UBS analyst Brent Thill in a research report Tuesday.Analysts estimate Q4 revenue of $372 million and EPS minus items of 23 cents, up from 20 cents in the year earlier period. The 33% revenue growth is strong but the percentage continues to slip as the company gets bigger. That year-over-year growth is down from 37% in Q3, 38% in Q2 and 44% in Q1.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer-Software Enterprise group ranks No. 87 out of 197 industry groups. Paycom Software has the highest Composite Rating, an important metric in CAN SLIM investing. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, analysts project EPS ex items of 18 cents, doubling Q1 2016, and $403.2 million in revenue, up 32%. Analysts estimate full-year 2017 revenue of $1.8 billion, up 32%.ServiceNow's main competitors include CA, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), IBM (IBM) and Salesforce.com (CRM).ServiceNow stock fell 14% in 2016, but shares have moved above their 50-day moving average in January, with a buy point of 89.89. ServiceNow stock rose 0.9 to 83.97 in the stock market today.ServiceNow's core business is software for information technology service management, or ITSM. ServiceNow has expanded into human resources, customer service and security software.Billings growth stabilized after slowing in 2015, when the company reorganized sales."We continue to view ServiceNow as one of the select few in software to sustain 30%-plus subscription billings growth with free cash flow margins comfortably above 25% over the next years," said Keith Weiss, a Morgan Stanley analyst, in a report.RELATED:Salesforce.com Stock Rallies In 2017 As Top Software PickServiceNow Price Target Hits 100 On Earnings Beat

San Francisco-based AppDynamics, which makes software companies use to analyze the performance of their apps, on Wednesday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to make an initial public offering, looking to raise up to $100 million.The company filed under the JOBS (Jumpstart Our Business Startups) Act. It did not set an expected price range, but it listed as underwriters some of Wall Street's biggest firms, including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley.AppDynamics reported revenue of $158.4 million for the nine months ended Oct. 31, up 54% from the year-earlier period. It reported losses of $95.1 million for the recent nine-month period, vs. $92.4 million in losses for the year-earlier period.IBD'S TAKE: Arista Networks had been among the best-performing IPOs this year. What are some others? Check IBD's IPO Leaders to track the best of the new issues.It listed competitors ranging from tech giants Microsoft (MSFT) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to New Relic (NEWR), which made its IPO two years ago and remains in the red.The company listed among its customers Capital One Financial (COF), IBM (IBM), Charter Communications (CHTR), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Expedia (EXPE).AppDynamics estimates its total addressable market at $12 billion, with products that touch on the markets for IT operations, data analytics and business intelligence."Our integrated suite of applications monitors the performance of software applications and IT infrastructures, down to the underlying code, and automatically correlates them into logical 'business transactions,' such as booking a flight in a web browser, transferring money on a mobile device, getting directions through a car's navigation system or locating physical goods in an inventory system," the company said in its S-1 filing.It's been the slowest IPO market since the Great Recession, though things are expected to heat up early in 2017 with an IPO by Snapchat owner Snap. Some expect that could open the door to other so-called "unicorns," the nickname for tech startups valued at more than $1 billion. AppDynamics' investments reportedly value the company near $2 billion.Nutanix (NTNX) and Twilio (TWLO) were among the few unicorns to launch in 2016, and both stocks had their moments. Acacia Communcations (ACIA) also had been a hot IPO after its May launch, but Acacia, Nutanix and Twilio are now trading well off their highs. RELATED: Tech Unicorn Nutanix Gets Positive CoverageSnapchat Owner Files For Confidential IPO

Stocks opened effectively flat Friday ahead of the upcoming three-day Christmas holiday weekend.The Dow industrials and the S&P 500 edged lower; the Nasdaq composite hung a fraction higher while the Russell 2000 gained 0.2%.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both head into Friday's session up 0.1% on the week, flat-lining for a second straight week. The Dow is up 0.4%, showing a 4.2% gain so far in December. The S&P 500 has a 2.8% gain so far for the month. The Nasdaq is up 2.3%.Small caps slowed for a second straight week, with both the S&P Smallcap 600 and the Russell 2000 down 0.1%. Since the start of December, the S&P 600 is up 3.6% and the Russell 2000 holds a 3.1% gain.Pfizer (PFE) reversed its early 2% loss and gained 0.5%. The company announced it had completed the acquisition of an AstraZeneca (AZN) division that specializes in fighting infections, a deal involving a $550 million upfront payment and up to $600 in sales-related performance payments. Pfizer shares have been in a mild consolidation since July. AstraZeneca shares rose 0.6% ahead of the open.Boeing (BA) inched up after reporting a deal for four Next Generation 737-800 jets with U.K.-based airline Jet2.com. The aircraft list prices total $384 mil.Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE) added 1% in premarket trade but was flat at the open. The information technology and enterprise services unit of the recently divided company ended Thursday's session up 56% so far for the year, and in buy range above a 23.63 buy point in a flat base.Discount retailer Fred's (FRED) jumped 2%, adding to recent big gains. News reports said hedge fund Alden Global Capital had taken a 25% stake in the chain, which operates about 650 stores. Fred's shares spiked 80% on Tuesday, after the company reported plans to buy 865 stores being divested by RiteAid (RAD) as part of its merger with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA). Tuesday's gain took back most of the ground Fred's shares had lost in an 18-month correction.Cintas (CTAS) dropped more than 4% after a fiscal second-quarter report late Thursday met analysts expectations straight across all columns.  The stock had been hovering around a 120.04 buy point in a cup base for three weeks.Shares of Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) jumped more than 2% after reporting quarterly results late Thursday. The stock is trying to cross back above its 200-day line.Friday's economic calendar keeps things simple: At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan offers its final take on December consumer sentiment and new home sales numbers for November are expected from the Commerce Department. At 1 p.m. ET, Baker Hughes (BHI) delivers its weekly rig count. The bond market closes early today, at 2 p.m., ahead of the holiday.Crude oil narrowed its early declines, with West Texas Intermediate down 0.6% and holding above $52 a barrel. Gold edged up 0.1% to $1,131.50 an ounce. The dollar backtracked a bit vs. the euro and the yen, although markets in Tokyo were closed for Japan's Emperor's Birthday holiday. Bonds eased, with the 10-year-yield down 2 basis point to 2.53%.Overseas markets were generally quiet. Benchmark indexes in China booked mild losses Friday. In Europe, markets shifted to mixed action, trading in a very tight range in afternoon trade.RELATED:Wal-Mart, Target Drop Amid Tariff Talk: Investing Action PlanHow To Invest: Pearls Of Trading Wisdom From Wall Street's Gerald LoebIBD Stock Spotlight: Why These High-Yield Natural Gas Midstream Plays Deserve Attention

Technology giant IBM (IBM) on Tuesday remained in the buy zone it retook last week, but an investment bank threw cold water on theories that Big Blue might be in the early stages of a turnaround.With shares up and the company's so-called "strategic imperatives" revenue expected to rise 14% in 2016, "there is a temptation to call this the beginning of a turnaround at IBM," Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha wrote in a research report Tuesday. "However, our closer examination highlights that a series of nonoperational, nonrecurring items are supporting the EPS."We believe the structural profitability may continue to erode."IBD'S TAKE: IBM hit a 52-week high last week, but which stocks are touching that level now? Quite a few, but always a good idea to parse these stocks by strength, which you find in IBD's New Highs. The companies are ranked by Composite Rating, which is based on key metrics such as earnings and sales growth.Garcha, who has an underperform rating on IBM stock, lowered his estimate for 2017 earnings per share to $12.64 from $12.74, vs. Wall Street consensus of $13.90.IBM stock, however, rose 1.7% to 168.25 in the stock market today. On Wednesday, the stock retook a 161.96 buy point out of a cup-with-handle base, and it's trading at 17-month highs.IBM battles companies such as Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), Oracle (ORCL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) to be an overall technology services provider for businesses and other enterprises.Big Blue's year-over-year revenue has fallen the past 18 straight quarters, but by just 0.3% in Q3. The company has turned its focus to what it calls its strategic imperatives: cloud, mobile, security, data analytics and social business.In the meantime, though, Garcha says actions that have helped shore up its EPS in the past are less effective. He sees the company seeing lower returns from its intellectual property, for example. He says stock buybacks have helped but have "led to an underinvestment in R&D."He also says the job cuts and workforce rebalancing taking place at the company over the past five years "has become less and less effective."RELATED:IBM Among Megacaps At Buy Points; GE, Home Depot, Comcast, TooIBM CEO Among Those To Attend Trump Tech Summit

Apple (AAPL) needs to dramatically increase its cash dividends if it wants to entice investors to buy its stock, Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White said Wednesday.The Cupertino, Calif.-based consumer electronics giant has posted three straight quarters of declining sales and earnings on a year-over-year basis. For the current quarter, Apple's fiscal Q1, Wall Street is modeling a 2% increase in sales and a 2% decrease in earnings per share.Investors are looking to the Fall 2017 release of the iPhone 8 as the next major catalyst for the stock. But White says the company could create interest in the stock before then by increasing its dividend yield to that of its peers. Apple traditionally updates its capital return program in April, when it releases fiscal Q2 results."Given the roller coaster ride that Apple investors continue to find themselves on each year, we believe Apple should materially hike its dividend yield to a range of 3.5% to 4.0% (vs. 2.1% now) to attract more value investors that can act as a steadying force during rough patches," White said in a research report. "The excuse that Apple's stock is so cheap, the company can buy back more shares (vs. a material dividend hike), is wearing thin."IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has been below its 50-day moving average, a negative sign, since Nov. 1. More attractive stocks for investors to consider can be found on the IBD 50 list of top growth companies.Apple should significantly increase its dividend even without a repatriation of foreign profits, he said. President-elect Donald Trump has proposed a corporate tax holiday on foreign profits."Repatriation or no repatriation, we believe Apple should meaningfully hike its dividend," White said. "Already, Cisco (CSCO), IBM (IBM) and HP Enterprise (HPE) are sporting a dividend yield of approximately 3.5%. When will Apple join the party?"White reiterated his buy rating on Apple stock with a price target of 185.Apple rose 1% to 111.03 on the stock market today, working on a flat base with a possible buy point of 118.79. But shares are still trading below their 50-day line.RELATED:Are Apple, FANG Stocks Ready To Join The Trump Rally?Trump Targets Drug Prices, Apple, Seeks '5 Minutes' With Offshoring FirmsSquare Stock Gains On Apple Pay Mobile Partnership

Nutanix's (NTNX) fiscal Q1 top-line beat late Tuesday came from strong spending by federal government customers and a marketing partnership with Dell Technologies[ticker symb=DVMT], but competition from Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is mounting, analysts say.The results prompted at least three investment banks to hike their price tagets on Nutanix stock. Piper Jaffray bumped up its PT to 40 from 36, RBC Capital to 38 from 36 and Pacific Crest Securities to 38 from 37.Nutanix stock nevertheless tumbled 6.2% to 31.97 in the stock market today, its biggest one-day decline since Oct. 28.Nutanix ported a wider loss in the October quarter, but that still beat Wall Street views as revenue and billings topped expectations."The emphatic top-line beat was driven by record performance in the federal vertical, better-than-expected OEM, strong adoption of the Nutanix platform across global 2000 customers, and a growing international presence," Jason Ader, a William Blair analyst, said in a research report. "While the recent entry of HPE and Cisco into the hyper-converged infrastructure market conjures up fears of commoditization, we view it as a major validation of the market and thus a significant positive for Nutanix, at least in the near term."IBD'S TAKE: Nutanix stock soared its first two days of trading then plunged, but shares had been clawing back. Other tech IPOs, such as Acacia Communications, have also been choppy. Learn more about The Trade Desk and other newly public companies at IBD'S IPO Center. San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix said revenue for the quarter ended Oct. 31 popped 90% to $167 million as billings jumped 87% to $239 million. Nutanix reported a non-GAAP loss of 37 cents a share, up from a 27-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Analysts had projected a 44-cent loss on revenue of $152.2 million and billings of $214 million."Nutanix reported a strong debut as a public company, easily outperforming consensus expectations on all metrics, driven by large deal strength that benefited from impressive cross-selling trends and better-than-expected Dell OEM business," said Matthew Hedberg, an analyst at RBC Capital, in a report.Nutanix went public at 16 per share on Sept. 30, raising $238 million. The stock peaked in its second day of trading, at 46.78. It appears to be forming its first base, but a buy point is not evident yet.Nutanix's software manages network, storage and server infrastructure in private cloud platforms, an emerging market called "hyperconvergence." Most revenue comes from Nutanix-branded appliances, but the company's sales mix is shifting to software that runs on partner hardware."Management said it expects to reach positive FCF (free cash flow) by the end of fiscal Q2 2018, addressing some broader market concerns about the rate of spending and track to profitability among higher-growth data center providers," said Alex Kurtz, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, in a report.RELATED:Cisco, HPE Rival Nutanix Posts Q1 Beat, But Stock FallsTech Unicorn Nutanix Embraced With Positive Coverage Post-IPOCisco, HPE View: Overseas Cash Trumps Cautious Outlooks

PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) late Tuesday reported in-line earnings per share on better-than-expected sales for its fiscal fourth quarter, but it disappointed investors with its current-quarter EPS guidance.HP stock was down 2% in after-hours trading following the earnings news release. During the regular session, HP fell a fraction to 15.95 on the stock market today.HP earned 36 cents a share excluding items, up 20% year over year, on sales of $12.51 billion, up 2%, in the quarter ended Oct. 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected HP to generate sales of $11.9 billion, down 2%, in Q4.It was HP's first quarter of sales growth since it split from Hewlett-Packard a year ago. That transaction also spawned Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which edged expectations with its earnings report late Tuesday.For its current fiscal Q1, HP guided to non-GAAP earnings per share of 35 to 38 cents. It did not give a revenue target.Wall Street had been modeling HP to earn 38 cents a share ex items, up 6%, on sales of $11.59 billion, down 5%.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has a middle-of-the-road IBD Composite Rating of 50. But there are more attractive stocks out there for investors to consider. Read this week's installment of the IBD feature Stocks Near A Buy Zone.HP's PC revenue rose 4% in Q4, helped by strong notebook sales. Printing revenue fell 8%.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company is in a rebuilding mode. Last month, HP announced a cost-cutting plan that will result in the elimination of 3,000 to 4,000 jobs over the next three years. HP is facing an uncertain PC market and has been working to rightsize its printing supplies business."We delivered on our full-year financial commitments and executed well on our strategy to protect our core, drive growth and invest in our future all while taking cost out of the business," HP CEO Dion Weisler said in a statement. "As we've proved quarter over quarter, we are confident in our abilities to execute and deliver, while making business decisions focused on the long-term success for the company."RELATED:HP Gains On Lenovo In PCs; Apple Mac Sales Tumble

Nutanix (NTNX) reported a wider loss in fiscal Q1 that still beat views as revenue and billings topped expectations. Current-quarter guidance also beat analyst views, but shares in the provider of data center management software fell in late trading.San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix said revenue for the quarter ended Oct. 31 popped 90% to $167 million as billings jumped 87% to $239 million. Nutanix reported a non-GAAP loss of 37 cents a share, up from a 27-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Analysts had projected a 44-cent loss on revenue of $152.2 million and billings of $214 million.In the current quarter, Nutanix forecast revenue of $177.5 million at the midpoint of its guidance range and a per-share loss minus items of 35 cents to 36 cents vs. consensus estimates of $168 million and a 37-cent loss.Nutanix reported earnings for the first time as a publicly traded company, after making its IPO in September.Nutanix stock was down 3% in after-hours trading in the stock market today, after posting its earnings. Shares rose 2.2% to 34.09 in the regular session.Nutanix competes with Cisco Systems (CSCO), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), VMware (VMW) and startup Simplivity, while partners include Dell Technologies (DVMT) and Lenovo.IBD'S TAKE: Nutanix stock soared its first two days of trading then plunged, but shares had been clawing back. Other tech IPOs, such as Acacia Communications, have also been choppy. Learn more about The Trade Desk and other newly public companies at IBD'S IPO Center. Nutanix's software manages network, storage and server infrastructure in private cloud platforms, an emerging market called "hyperconvergence." Most revenue comes from Nutanix-branded appliances, but the company's sales mix is shifting to software that runs on partner hardware. Nutanix's software enable customers to reduce IT staffing, analysts say.Nutanix went public at 16 per share on Sept. 30, raising $238 million. The stock peaked in its second day of trading, at 46.78.Analysts expect Nutanix's product strategy to evolve toward hybrid, private-public cloud infrastructure. Amazon Web Services, the cloud computing arm of Amazon.com (AMZN); Microsoft (MSFT) and Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) might compete with Nutanix down the road as they push into private data centers, analysts say.AWS, Microsoft and Google are the biggest providers of infrastructure-as-a-service, where customers rent computing resources via the internet. IBM (IBM), another cloud player, has claimed Nutanix infringed on at least five of its U.S. patents.RELATED:Tech Unicorn Nutanix Embraced With Positive Coverage Post-IPOCisco, HPE View: Overseas Cash Trumps Cautious Outlooks

HP Inc. (HPQ) is making "Star Wars"-themed personal computers, but the Force definitely wasn't with the PC and printer maker late Tuesday when it reported fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings.HP's PC and printer businesses brought in revenue of $12.66 billion in fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 14.2% year over year. The PC and printer businesses racked up earnings before taxes of $1.16 billion, down 18%.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company also gave disappointing guidance.For the current quarter, its fiscal Q1, HP expects earnings per share minus items of 33 to 38 cents, vs. analyst expectations for 42 cents. On a GAAP basis, it is targeting EPS of 27 to 32 cents, vs. Wall Street's view of 38 cents.For fiscal 2016, ending Oct. 31, 2016, HP expects to earn $1.59 to $1.69 a share excluding items, where analysts were modeling for $1.71. On a GAAP basis, its EPS guidance was in line with forecasts, at $1.50 to $1.60 vs. expectations for $1.54.HP did not give sales guidance.HP stock plunged 14% Wednesday, to 12.64.Needham analyst David Rold downgraded HP stock to hold from buy on Wednesday.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um on Tuesday cut his valuation range on HP stock to 14.50 to 16, down from 16.50 to 18, but he continues to rate HP stock as outperform.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin reiterated his sector weight rating on HP stock, which he said was fairly valued between 13.50 and 14.'Consolidating Markets'The PC and printer markets are likely to be challenging for several more quarters, HP CEO Dion Weisler said on the company's earnings conference call with analysts."Q4 was a difficult quarter and somewhat weaker than we expected," he said. HP remains a leader in two "large, consolidating markets," he said.The PC market has been tough, especially in the consumer segment, because of elevated sales channel inventory, Weisler said.Also, Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system has yet to spark a rebound in PC sales.But on the commercial side of the PC business, HP achieved its highest market share position ever at 23.7%, Weisler said."We believe that innovation and sprinkles of magic are key to differentiation as the PC market goes through consolidation," Weisler said. He pointed to the company's new lineup of enterprise and consumer PCs, including a Star Wars Special Edition Notebook PC made in partnership with Walt Disney (DIS) and Lucasfilm.The former Hewlett-Packard split into two companies on Nov. 1. HP Inc. sells personal computers and printers, while Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) sells information technology hardware, software and services to corporations and other enterprises. HP Inc. and HPE reported results together Tuesday, as Q4 was their last quarter together before their split."Both companies are off and running," Meg Whitman, chairman of HP Inc. and chairman and CEO of HPE, said on the call. "Each company has a clear, well-defined strategy and is well positioned to win in its respective market."In Q4, HP's PC unit sales were down 12% from the year-earlier quarter, with desktops down 17% and notebooks down 5%. HP has walked away from volume PC deals that don't meet its profit margin targets, Weisler said.HP's printer hardware unit sales were down 17%, with commercial units down 23% and consumer units down 14%. Supplies revenue was down 10%.Speaking on CNBC on Wednesday, Whitman said HP Inc. performed well in a "tough PC market."While Windows 10 hasn't provided a catalyst yet for PC upgrades, she still says that will happen."There's nearly 450 million PCs out there that are older than 4-1/2 years," she said. "And at some point, our belief is that people are going to upgrade those PCs. And I think HP Inc. is well positioned when that happens."Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter @IBD_PSeitz and on Facebook.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock jumped as much as 8.5% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday posted fiscal Q4 revenue that beat views and guided fiscal 2016 performance better than analysts expected.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended the day at 14.12, up 3.1%."Our overall opinion on HPE remains unchanged" after the earnings call, wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research report. He said the stock "already reflects an anticipated stabilization in some of its most troubled areas."He said positives include growth in large, tier-one hyperscale servers, while negatives included a decline in services revenue."Overall, the outlook for FY16 is unchanged (albeit more back-end loaded) and the stock is likely range-bound at current levels," said Kugele, who maintained a hold rating on HPE stock.Responding to those who say HPE isn't selling enough services and products in the cloud, company CEO Meg Whitman told CNBC Wednesday that spending for private cloud products — networks and data centers that businesses keep in-house, which is HPE's focus — is growing as fast as public cloud. "Most people don't understand that," she said."Yesterday, we announced that we were partnering with Microsoft (MFST) Azure to provide the public cloud," she told CNBC. "And then we have this great cloud system automation that helps you orchestrate your clouds in your data center. So if you think about where the money is spent today, interestingly, still about 85% of the spend is in traditional I.T. ... The next-biggest segment is private cloud. And the next after that is public cloud. And private and public cloud are growing at about the same rate."So we are going right to the heart of what our customers are asking. And I feel really good about our strategy and excited about the partnership that we announced yesterday with Microsoft Azure."Microsoft Azure competes with market leader Amazon Web Services, a unit of Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and others in providing public cloud services.Needham's Kugele liked the Azure partnership and the fact that HPE was "abdicating" in the public cloud sector, but he pointed out that Azure is fighting against AWS, "and ultimate success is going to be a marathon and not a sprint."New Era BeginsEnterprise is roughly half — most analysts say the more promising half — of the Nov. 1 split of the legendary 76-year-old Hewlett-Packard Co. The other half, HP Inc. (HPQ), focuses on the PC and printer businesses, and it kept the old HPQ ticker.The Q4 report was the last for the old company, which Whitman also chaired. It earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Enterprise's pro forma portion of Q4 sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion but was up 3% in constant currency. Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion.Enterprise reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.Whitman told analysts in the conference call following Tuesday's earnings release that HPE "will double down on our private and managed cloud (efforts), and sunset our public cloud." Of "the move to a hybrid cloud environment ... you can expect to hear more."Needham analyst Kugele said that with HPE still on its way to 30,000 layoffs, and the service business determined to "drag its margins higher through careful contract signings, we are most focused on the storage and server opportunity for HPE. In servers, the lumpy buying pattern of tier-1 hyperscale customers helped them in the quarter but is hardly consistently reliable."Nevertheless we expect the segment to show slight growth in fiscal '16."He said storage has benefited from "aggressive pricing," but he sees more competition from rivals such as NetApp (NTAP) and Pure Storage (PSTG)."Bottom line, there are more puts and takes and caveats than investors should accept in a long thesis," Kugele wrote. "Staying on the sidelines."

Thin opening gains firmed in early action Wednesday following a flood of primarily positive economic news. The Nasdaq rolled ahead 0.3%, while the Dow and the S&P 500 held to 0.1% gains.Volume faded about 20% each on the NYSE and the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time on Tuesday.The stock market today launched to a heavy slate of economic news, led by better than expected — or at least as good as expected — October durable goods orders, weekly unemployment claim and personal income numbers.The preliminary services sector estimate from researcher Markit was also positive, with its Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 56.5 for November, up from 54.4 and above economist projections of 55. Employment gains aided the bounce off October's nine-month low, but business confidence remained subdued, the report said.Also above expectation: the Federal Housing Finance Agency's September House Price Index, which leaped 0.8%, up from August's 0.3% rise and vs. consensus projections for an 0.4% rise.New home sales jumped to an annualized rate of 495,000 in October, the Commerce Department reported. The reports also revised September's rate lower, to 447,000. Economist consensus had forecast a November increase to a rate of 499,000 homes sold.The University of Michigan offered the morning's leading down note. The final reading of its November Consumer Sentiment Index dipped to 91.3 — above October's tally of 90 but down from a preliminary November estimate of 93.1 and below views for no change.Oil prices were still down more than 1%, but losses eased a bit on the approach to the Energy Information Administration's 10:30 a.m. weekly report on inventories.Oil-related stocks held eight of the 10 worst losses among S&P 500 companies in early action. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) posted to the worst opening declines on the Dow.In other stocks, nothing runs like a Deere, the ads say, and that was true Wednesday morning as Deere (DE) led the S&P 500 after narrowing a 5% gain to 3%. The agricultural and construction equipment maker reported its fiscal fourth quarter earnings fell less than consensus forecasts. The stock is trying to climb off the floor of a three-month consolidation.Freshly halved PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) dived 13% at the start of trade. IT services and equipment sibling Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) surged 6%. The company late Tuesday reported its last full quarter as a combined outfit, following the Nov. 1 split into separate operations.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) charged ahead almost 4%, continuing its rebound from its week-ago low. The stock is deep in a year-long correction, attempting to retake support at its 10-week moving average.Electronic Arts (EA) jumped 3%, attempting to bounce back from the two-day sell-off that appeared to follow comments from retailer GameStop (GME) that sales of EA's Star Wars Battlefront were weaker than expected.On the IBD 50 list, Euronet Worldwide (EEFT) climbed more than 2% at the start of trade. It put the stock in buying range on a rebound from its 10-week moving average. It is the first test since the ATM and card payment processor broke out above a cup base in September.China-based online game provider NetEase (NTES) added nearly 2%. The stock is working on its seventh straight gain and is extended above a 154.98 buy point.Overseas, Europe's market powered higher following mostly positive U.S. economic news. Benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded higher in afternoon action, led by Frankfurt's DAX, up 1.7%.

Stocks pared intraday gains to close narrowly mixed ahead of Thanksgiving Day. The Nasdaq led with a 0.3% gain, the Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally higher and the S&P 500 was slightly lower. Volume was sharply lower across the board vs. Tuesday, according to preliminary data — not surprising for the day before Thanksgiving.
Winners topped losers by a 3-2 margin on the NYSE and 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.

Automakers were among top gainers in the stock market today, thanks to Tesla's (TSLA) 5% move sparked by a bullish Credit Suisse report. IBD 50 stock Monster Beverage (MNST) rose 3% to clear a 154 cup-with-handle buy point and boost the nonalcoholic beverage group.

Among other IBD 50 stocks, Universal Display (OLED) led gainers with a 7% pop in heavy volume as it builds the right side of a steep, cup-shaped base with a 55.93 buy point. Shares surged 22% last week on comments by CFO Sidney Rosenblatt that Apple (AAPL) supplier Foxconn ordered OLED manufacturing equipment for 2017. He also said he thinks "it's only a matter of time" before Apple starts using OLED technology in its products.

Foreign banks lagged as Argentine bank holding company Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) sank 5% in heavy volume for a third straight down session. It triggered a sell signal Monday after giving up a double-digit gain from a 26.23 buy point.

HP (HPQ) gapped down and fell 13% in fast trade after the PC and printer maker late Tuesday reported quarterly results and issued weak guidance. It was its last report as a combined company with Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which was spun off earlier this month. The spinoff's shares gained 3%.

Stock futures stuck to steady, slender gains ahead of Wednesday's open as investors dug through a trove of fresh economic news and earnings reports.Dow futures flew straight and level, up 33.8 points. Nasdaq 100 futures showed a 10.2-point gain. S&P 500 futures traded 2.6 points above fair market value.The stock market today gets a bellyful of economic news, as government agencies clear the decks before their Thanksgiving break.Personal income jumped 0.4% — in line with estimates — in October, the Commerce Department reported, while revising its September estimate upward to 0.2%. A 0.1% gain in consumer spending stopped short of projections for a 0.3% improvement. Prices popped 0.1%, reversing September's 0.1% decline, but stopping short of projections for a 0.2% increase. Core prices, minus energy and food, were flat — below expectations for a 0.2% gain.The Commerce Department also said durable goods orders jumped 3% in October, and revised September's decline from 1.2% to 0.8%. Orders for commercial aircraft boosted October's numbers. Minus transportation, orders rose a slimmer 0.5%. Economists had projected an overall 1.5% gain for the month and a 0.4% improvement minus transportation.Jobless claims slowed to 260,000 in the week ended Nov. 21, down more than 4% from the prior week and better than estimates for a slight decline to 270,000 claims. The Labor Department also reported the four-week moving average continued to tick higher, to 271,000.The Federal Housing Finance Agency sets out its September Housing Price Index at 9 a.m. ET. Researcher Markit reports its preliminary service purchasing managers' index for November at 9:45. At 10 a.m., look for October new-home sales from the Commerce Department and a final November consumer sentiment estimate from the University of Michigan.Oil will be in focus later this morning, when the Energy Information Administration releases its weekly inventories data at 10:30. In early trading, oil prices erased most of their gains from Tuesday, down nearly 2%. Nymex gasoline futures fell almost 3%.The majority of Dow stocks remained flat ahead of the open. Pfizer (PFE) led the handful of gainers with a 0.9% advance. Intel (INTC) dropped 0.8%, the biggest decline.The flow of earnings reports had slowed to a trickle, but still continued to kick up major moves.Apparel retailer Guess (GES) powered up 7% after a solid Q3 report late Tuesday. China-based social networking site Momo (MOMO) popped 6%, despite a sales and earnings miss, as its monthly active users rose 21% to 73 million in September.Deere (DE) cranked up a 5% advance as its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings fell to $1.08 a share, far above consensus views for a fall to 75 cents. Revenue fell 26%, also better than expected. Management's outlook essentially said sales would deteriorate at an improved pace. Deere shares are in a three-month consolidation, ending Tuesday 22% below an August high.Hewlett Packard's two companies went in different directions following their first quarterly report released since the Nov. 1 divorce.HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer manufacturer, tumbled 9% after announcing late Tuesday it sees fiscal Q1 and full-year earnings below consensus expectations. HP shares ended Tuesday 33% above an early October low, working to climb the right side of a 10-month consolidation.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), the information technology hardware, software and service unit, was up 5% before the open. HPE shares have been consolidating since their Nov. 1 launch.In their last quarter as a combined company, HP's earnings and revenue fell further than expected by analysts.Leading stocks were predominately quiet in premarket trade, with stocks on the IBD 50 and Your Weekly Review lists holding to gains or losses of less than 1%.Overseas, markets across Asia were narrowly mixed, with the leading indexes in Hong Kong and Tokyo posting mild losses. European markets bounced higher after harsh losses on Tuesday. Benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded up around 1% at midday.
